<p>4 &nbsp;Overall Assessment....................................................................................................12</p>
<p>Appendices</p>
<p>A &nbsp;RiskWarnings</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 1<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Introduction</p>
<p>1.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Objective of evaluation</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance has assigned William M. Mercer Ltd to evaluate each AP<br>Fund. The objective of the assignment is to evaluate each Fund’s organisational<br>structure and investment policy, and to appraise this structure in light of the mandate<br>given it. The evaluation of the organisation will focus on the risk Controls and the<br>Fund’s ongoing compliance with the objectives set by its Board. The evaluation of the<br>Investment Policy will cover overall methodology, objectives and assumptions used<br>when performing the Asset Liability Study.</p>
<p>Our review is based on reviewing working papers and documents provided by the<br>funds, telephone conversations and an onsite visit. We would like to stress that our<br>mandate was limited to carrying out a high level review of the Funds not a detailed<br>due diligence of the organisation and the investment policy setting.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of the AP Funds’ respective mandates</p>
<p>The First to Fourth and Sixth AP Funds have mandates to manage the buffer funds in<br>the new reformed pension system. The First AP Fund represents the new name for<br>what was formerly known as part of the First - Third Fund Board. The First and Third<br>Fund Boards have been reorganised into the First AP Fund (First and Third Fund<br>Board) and Second AP Fund (Second Fund Board).</p>
<p>As from the start of 2001, new investment rules came into force for the First to Fourth<br>AP Funds, and as result each are initially managing approximately SEK 134 billion.<br>According to legislation the First to Fourth AP Funds must manage the assets in order<br>to provide a high long-term return, satisfactory liquidity, good risk diversification and<br>a good margin of security.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of key responsibilities of the Board</p>
<p>Each AP Fund has a team of permanent staff responsible for putting into effect the<br>decisions taken by the Fund’s goveming Board.</p>
<p>The number of Board members for each Fund (with the exception of the Sixth AP<br>Fund) is set to 9 members. The Government nominates all members of the Board. Two<br>of the members are nominated from employer organisations and two are nominated<br>from employee organisations. The main responsibilities are to establish the investment<br>policy, govemance policy and Risk Control Plan. The Board can delegate<br>responsibilities to the MD/CEO.</p>
<p>Divyesh Hindocha</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Johan Sidenmark</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 1<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Review of organisation</p>
<p>2.1 Review of organisation</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund inherited the organisation from the First - Third Fund Board.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The organisation is divided between the Strategic Allocation, Investment, and<br>Administration.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The complete organisation of 65 employees (as at the start 2001) is illustrated in<br>the organisation chart below:</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-412.png" style="width:77pt;height:22pt;"/>
<p>MD/CEO</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-413.png" style="width:252pt;height:194pt;"/>
<p>The First AP Fund organisation was the former First - Third Fund Board and in<br>effect has been downsized going from Skr 600 billion in Assets under<br>management to Skr 150 billion.</p>
<p>This Fund is slightly different from the others on two organisational counts. The<br>first, is the decision to separate out a Strategic Asset Allocation function from<br>the Investment Department. The idea is to have a group operating as a “think<br>tank”, away from the noise of everyday markets, to make occasional strategic</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 1<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>decisions to deviate under pre-set limits from the Reference Portfolio. These<br>would be long term views on countries, sectors, themes or asset classes. The<br>decisions taken by this group receive no formal input from the investment<br>professionals, and are in effect handed down to the investment department as<br>their new strategic benchmark. The investment group will then additionally have<br>leeway to implement shorter-term tactical decisions around this benchmark,<br>reyiewing and setting a risk budget every week, around an overall fund tracking<br>error target of 3%. The strategic allocation group is comprised of the CEO, a<br>senior economist and some analyst support.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The other organisational difference is the relatively high staffing of the<br>Administration Department, currently numbering 11 people.</p>
<p>2.2 Management of Assets</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The philosophy is mainly to try generating returns on active allocation of Capital<br>between and within different asset classes. The foundation for this will be<br>fundamental and quantitative analysis. The ALM will set the Reference Portfolio<br>which the Board of Directors has endorsed.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The strategic asset allocation consists of... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Swedish equity is managed actively in-house and this is likely to continue.<br>Initially the foreign equity allocation is to be managed passively.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fixed income portfolios consist of an allocation to credit (mainly Swedish<br>and US). In the main, the management of this is carried out in-house, however<br>some of the US credit is managed by an extemal manager.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund is planning to conduct an exercise to identify the areas of added value<br>from active management and the extent to which this activity should be carried<br>out in house or by extemal managers.</p>
<p>• The current thinking (expressed by the CIO) is to employ a “bar-bell”<br>(core/satellite) strategy for non-Swedish equity exposure. The Fund still needs to<br>develop its thinking in this area and the process designed. The additional<br>decision is internal versus extemal for active management. The Fund has started<br>quite cautiously, utilising mostly passive strategies, but will gradually seek to<br>add more value with active strategies.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The currency management is carried out in house (using inputs from two<br>extemal managers) and the Fund is considering the appointment of a currency<br>overlay manager.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The risk parameters and investment restrictions set by Board control the Fund’s<br>activities.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The risk mandate delegated by the Board of Directors is controlled by an<br>independent Risk Control Unit. Although the organisational chart shows that the<br>Risk Unit falls under the Administration function, the Risk Unit reports directly<br>to the CEO and Board of Directors.</p>
<p>The Board of Directors decides the deviation guidelines from the Reference<br>Portfolio measured as Tracking Error. The CEO then allocates this risk budget<br>between the Strategic Allocation Group and the Investments Group. The basis of<br>the allocation of the risk budget has not been fully determined, the initial<br>thinking is to allocate the budget equally between the two activities.</p>
<p>The Strategic Asset Allocation is defined as deviations from the Reference<br>Portfolio that can give a better return and/or risk profile. The CEO and the<br>Strategic Asset Allocation Team will set the Strategic Asset Allocation as well<br>as setting the ranges for the tactical asset allocation and sector positions. The<br>Investments Group, headed by the CIO, has the responsibility of making short-<br>term tactical asset allocation decisions, as well as stock selection decisions. The<br>Strategic Asset Allocation can both include allocation between regions and<br>sectors with the investment decisions being based essentially on a “top-down”<br>view of the opportunity set.</p>
<p>The former First-Third Fund Board managed only fixed income assets internally<br>and it has kept that base of expertise, with an experienced team that even does<br>US credit with, we were told, success. The equity team is more recent and less<br>experienced and there is also a separate currency team of three. Currency is<br>viewed as a separate asset class. There is also a 4-person quant group, who help<br>with risk management issues and support the investment teams with the design<br>of various tools.</p>
<p>There is an overall fund Tracking Error target of 3% and the investment goal<br>was expressed as seeking to realise an information ratio of 0.3. The rationale for<br>a 3% target was not clear to us. Currently any breach of this will result in the<br>automatic closing down of positions.</p>
<p>They have adopted the “traffic light” approach to monitoring tracking error and<br>any encroachment into the red zone demands immediate action.</p>
<p>The Fund has risk a management group of 3 employees that will perform risk<br>control and an additional group of 3 people carrying out performance evaluation.<br>The group has the capacity and tools to produce all necessary reports. The focus<br>of the performance function is to monitor the position and to evaluate<br>performance.</p>
<p>The AP fund uses Citibank as custodian for non-Swedish assets, and Nordea as<br>custodian/transfer bank for Swedish assets. The clearing of trades is carried out<br>in-house.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 1<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The AP Fund uses TMS 2000 as front office system, which appears to have<br>good functionalities. This is complemented by bolt on systems, in particular in<br>the area of risk management, with Wilshire being used as it has equity as well as<br>fixed income functionality. The systems are supported by an intemal IT team of</p>
<p>9 people and it was described as the best support you could get.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The budgeted overall cost, defined as percentage of asset under management, is</p>
<p>10 basis points.</p>
<p>2.3 People</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In order to evaluate the organisation’s strength and consistency we need to<br>define the officers’ job descriptions with emphasis on responsibilities, adequacy<br>of resources and incentives.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Board main responsibilities:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decide the Fund’s long term investment strategy</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decided and establish instructions to the CEO and other parties</p>
<p>decide upon policies</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decide the Business/Activity Plan for the Fund</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ongoing control and judgement of result of the investment operation</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;resource the Fund with adequate system</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decide upon new activities or the termination of old ones</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;recruit the CEO</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decide CEO’s terms of conditions including benefits</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CEO responsibilities:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;secure that the ongoing management and activities are in compliance with<br>the law, instructions and activity plans etc</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;implement Board decisions</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;report to the Board</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;establish instructions that are not established by the Board of Directors</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The issues are the same as previously discussed. There is a plan to introduce an<br>incentive plan by July 1 and this is under discussion with the Board.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Board members have a good balance of experience and expertise, with a<br>number having a financial background.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2.4 Mercer View</p>
<p>■ We would concur that in theory there is tremendous potential value-added from<br>both medium-term and short-term tactical asset allocation shifts. There is also a<br>great deal to be said for a “think tank” approach away from the fray. Although<br>this is still in the experimental phase, we can intuitively see some potential<br>problems on how this is set up, and we would simply suggest monitoring the<br>outcome of this carefully for a number of reasons:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;having accepted the high value-added of asset allocation decisions, they<br>are extremely difficult to forecast with any measure of consistency and at<br>an extreme can play havoc with what the ALM discipline set out to<br>accomplish at the outset.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;having accepted the need for extemal management generally, it is<br>interesting that this has not been considered for TAA (in any of the AP<br>Funds for that matter, at least to our knowledge), at least for a second<br>opinion and understanding of how specialists try to add value in this area.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the interfacing between strategic calls and tactical calls which are the<br>preserve of the investment group is not obvious, but they will clearly<br>impact on each other and the overall risk budgeting process. Conceivably<br>they might be at odds with each other.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;under certain circumstances, if the strategic decisions are not “bought in”<br>by the investment team, they might affect the accountability of the<br>investment professionals.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;while we were not able to judge this, we would be a little concemed that<br>“economists” would only look at a partial picture of what makes fmancial<br>markets tick.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;it would appear that the weekly cycle of meetings of the Strategic Asset<br>Allocation group is at odds with its medium term outlook.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;it will be very hard to value and measure the value added on the Tactical<br>level if the risk limits changes frequently.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fact of down-sizing the Assets under Management has not necessarily gone<br>down well internally where there is some question as to how efficient this may<br>prove to be.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Like all the other funds, AP1 is in a major transition process to implement the<br>new asset allocation. However, the Board has temporarily halted this process.<br>Normally, the approach to transition is rather mechanical to avoid the pitfalls of<br>market timing and getting something wrong. The best strategy is probably a<br>gradual phase in over time to smooth out market swings.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The overall approach would appear sensible. We accept the concept that some<br>measure of in-house management is useful to stay in touch with markets and in<br>this way to be in a better position to judge the actions of the extemal managers.<br>Under certain conditions a small team can deliver good results, and as long as<br>they are constantly benchmarked against extemal Solutions, it enables the fund<br>to keep open all of its options, which is good. One can also accept that good<br>investment professionals can find the environment of the AP Funds appealing,<br>with their focused attention on performance and hands on management when<br>compared to the distractions of large financial institutions in the rapidly<br>consolidating bank and insurance sectors.</p>
<p>The somewhat mechanical “stop loss” approach to Tracking Error violations, as<br>it was explained to us might be re-considered as it may prove detrimental to<br>performance in the long run. Extreme market conditions might explain short<br>term violations or dislocations between ex-ante expectations and ex-post<br>realised, but a stop loss reaction might be the wrong decision at the wrong time.<br>It is probably more important to clearly understand what is causing the violation<br>and whether the right decision is to accept a short term violation. Also it is not<br>clear to us the process that will be activated if the limit will be breached and how<br>and who will decide which positions to close down.</p>
<p>The decision to have a large administration is explained historically by the<br>decision to conduct in-house a number of clearing functions that would normally<br>be kept within the custodian bank. Apparently this decision was based on cost,<br>but even if this is still the case today, at the very least it causes the fund to lose<br>some focus at a time of major change and a move to global portfolios. This may<br>be worth looking into again.</p>
<p>Compared to the other AP Funds, there would appear to be less with regard to<br>structure and decision rules at every level (perhaps as a result of not starting<br>afresh). There would appear to be no formal compliance manual or job<br>descriptions, which would constitute best practice, although practices with<br>regard to personal dealings for instance are in place.</p>
<p>We would suggest that the risk definition be better rationalised (why 3%<br>tracking error as opposed to something else), perhaps this will come from the<br>intended review of the sources of added value that the Fund is anticipating<br>conducting.</p>
<p>We believe that the core/satellite approach may be a profitable strategy to adopt.<br>However by their nature satellite managers need to be monitored more carefully<br>and the Fund will need to be active in the management of the managers. The<br>Fund will need to have to be equipped to make the hire and fire judgements and<br>to do so relatively quickly. The Fund will need to put in place a framework that<br>allows it to make quick decisions in the context of the public tender process.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Like all the AP Funds right now, this is a period of major change and transition<br>management is a high priority. The overall approach would appear sensible and<br>the staff is clearly professional. We have some question as to whether the<br>medium and short-term tactical asset allocation decisions will not prove counter-<br>productive as opposed to adding value, but this should simply be monitored<br>carefully. Also the level of Administration should perhaps be re-assessed, both<br>on a cost comparison basis, but also on whether it does not distract the<br>organisation from what should be its main focus.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 ALM</p>
<p>3.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Objective Setting</p>
<p>• AP1 commissioned three studies to help them address the strategic asset<br>allocation issue in the “new” environment. The first study was to help them<br>define their goals and then establish a strategy within the context of their<br>investment restrictions . Two further studies were commissioned in the new<br>more liberal environment. One of these was described as “classical”, the second<br>as more “non-traditional”.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The studies themselves do not appear to discuss/analyse the overall pensions<br>system in detail. In discussions the Fund demonstrated a sound understanding of<br>the liability background to the study.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The studies focus on maintaining the overall buffer funds, or alternatively the<br>Balanstal, at a certain minimum level.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The optimisation was based on a long-term horizon (at least 10 years).</p>
<p>3.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Methodology/Assumptions</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The process identified a number of portfolios (the optimisation for this being<br>asset only). The expected as well as ‘best’ or ‘worst’ case of adopting the<br>different portfolios was analysed.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The asset and liability projections were independent.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The ‘returns’ measure used was the growth in buffer funds/Balanstal, and the<br>risk measure was the risk of the Balanstal falling below 100%</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Both the studies used standard mean variance methodologies to analyse<br>risk/return.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For expected returns, the assumption setting was based on the then bond yield<br>curves. Other asset return assumptions were built from the bond retum. For<br>example, the equity return was based on the historic outperformance of equity<br>over bond to determine an equity risk premium relative to bonds.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The starting point for risk and correlation assumptions was historical experience.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The assumptions put forward by the consultants who carried out the studies were<br>subject to debate with AP1. As a result, a number of the initial assumptions were<br>amended. For example, it was assumed after discussion that markets would<br>demonstrate greater correlation than has been the case historically (the rationale<br>for this being the increase in globalisation).</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There was some discussion on the expected return assumption to be used for;<br>Swedish equity, specifically the extent to which the return assumption should be<br>consistent with its higher volatility (ie higher than foreign equity). The Fund<br>decided to use the same return assumption for Swedish equity as for unhedged<br>foreign equities.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The studies used different asset classes in carrying out the optimisation process.<br>For example, one of the studies used a regional approach to both equities and<br>bonds. The other study used a tiered approach to equities using Swedish<br>equities, European equities and World (ex Europé) equities.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Both of the studies modelled ‘emerging’ market equities as a separate asset class<br>but did not model index-linked bonds.</p>
<p>3.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Analysis of Results &amp; Decisions</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The results of the studies were only one element in the decision-making process.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other considerations that were taken into account were;</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the link between the Income Index, the economy and the Swedish equity<br>market (weak).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the need to protect the system when the Swedish economy was not doing<br>so well.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the expected return of Swedish equities in future (in the context of it being<br>one of the best performing equity markets historically).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;the need to have a minimum of 30% in bonds.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the low liquidity of index-linked bonds.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The result of the discussion and analysis of ALM studies was to have a strategic<br>exposure to real assets (equities and real estate) of... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>3.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;Mercer View</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s strategic analysis has been detailed although as with all the AP<br>Funds, the process was hampered by uncertainty as to investment objectives.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is seldom possible to say defmitively that an investment strategy decision is<br>incorrect as it is a judgement entirely dependent upon risk tolerance and the need<br>to accept risk. Very high equity weightings could be justified in the context of<br>the AP Funds as could very low weightings. No real guidance is given to the AP<br>Funds in quantitative terms on the acceptable level of risk in the context of the<br>broader State pension system. The need to compete with other AP Funds<br>naturally drives funds towards high equity weightings, although such<br>considerations were not necessarily explicitly factored in to the Fund’s analysis.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is not clear how helpful/useful the ALM studies were in arriving at the final<br>decision. For example there is an explicit weighting to index-linked bonds in</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>10 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>the strategy however neither of the studies analysed index-linked bonds. Also<br>the studies do not address the bond investment in any detail.</p>
<p>The use of asset classes in the modelling is different from the decision in the end<br>of adopting a market-cap benchmark for the foreign equity exposure.</p>
<p>At least one of the studies has a US perspective/context, although this is<br>interesting, it is not clear to us what the relevance of this may be to AP1.</p>
<p>The final decision appears to have had a significant subjective overlay. In the<br>future, it may be worthwhile carrying out a more focused modelling exercise to<br>address/test specific issues.</p>
<p>Given the fixed income background of the Fund we were expecting perhaps a<br>more sophisticated approach to the analysis of bonds, their role in investment<br>strategy and the appropriate benchmark. Although this analysis may have been<br>done, we did not see any evidence of this.</p>
<p>Notwithstanding the above, the Fund showed a detailed understanding of the<br>main issues in question and appeared to have considered these carefully. They<br>had also thought carefully about the assumption setting process.</p>
<p>The most prominent deficiency in the ALM process, and one that all the Funds<br>faced, was effectively modelling a link between assets and liabilities beyond<br>purely inflation. It is this area in which we believe risk is most likely to be<br>understated. A link between recession, reduced contribution income and poor<br>equity returns is highly plausible and it is precisely this sort of scenario that will<br>adversely affect an equity-biased AP Fund to a potentially substantial degree.<br>More work needs to be undertaken in this area.</p>
<p>We would have liked the studies (or the subsequent analysis) to have considered<br>the objectives in more detail. We would have also liked to see a more visible<br>audit trail of the discussion that followed the receipt of the ALM studies to the<br>point that final decision on strategy was made. It is of course possible that this<br>audit trail is there, but given the Fund is in the process of implementing a change<br>in the strategy that this information is deemed to be confidential until the<br>transition is complete.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>11 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4 Overall Assessment</p>
<p>4.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section is intended to be an overall assessment based on our discussions with all<br>the Funds. Some of the points are more relevant to some Funds and less to others.</p>
<p>4.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have been impressed by the overall quality, experience and motivation of the<br>professionals that we met. Hard work has accomplished a great deal in a relatively<br>short time span, either to create a totally new organisation or to undertake a major re-<br>structuring of existing funds.</p>
<p>4.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In spite of new Board of Directors that include a varying proportion of non-initiated<br>people, they have also clearly risen to the challenge and have worked diligently with<br>management to set the framework for operating the system. To ensure their continuing<br>support, and although we understand the spirit of public service in Sweden, we wonder<br>if their remuneration could not be raised from the current SKr. 50,000 p.a.</p>
<p>4.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;We have the same kind of concerns regarding the compensation of the fund<br>professionals. While we can understand the attraction of the challenge of these new<br>funds for investment professionals, with the focus on hands on investment<br>management and an absence of bureaucracy compared with the mega-financial<br>institutions of today, at one point money does talk. Our concem is mostly on the bonus<br>side where the 6 months salary cap is clearly not in line with industry practice.<br>Personnel retention may become a real issue, especially as other third party managers<br>will come to view these people as providing an entry point into these funds. Although<br>we must emphasise that we have in no way detected this, it might be natural for<br>investment professionals to view a couple of years at an AP Fund in the same light and<br>good on a resumé. This is some thing we have observed with the investment teams of<br>Central Banks or Generational Funds. If this were to occur, it would clearly be<br>detrimental to the long term performance of the Funds.</p>
<p>4.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another aspect to this, is that it seem to us that the intent of the legislator in setting up<br>these competing funds was to generate a healthy competition to boost the overall risk<br>adjusted return of the buffer fund system. This would be better accomplished by a<br>clear linkage between value creation and remuneration, including short and longer<br>term incentives. The opposite risk in the absence of this linkage is that all the funds<br>will basically revert over time to a peer group average.</p>
<p>4.6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have found all the funds to place risk control at the forefront of their concerns<br>which is clearly within their mandate. By and large this is monitored in an appropriate<br>fashion in terms of its independence from investment management, reporting lines to<br>the CEO/Board and the type of reports. The only fundamental observation for possible<br>review, is that risk management cannot be condensed into one statistic, notably<br>tracking error, but must be reviewed in multiple cuts to understand the type of risk the<br>overall fund is taking and whether these are consistent with the house view or among<br>the various internal/external mandates. We suspect that for the most part this is being</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>12 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>done, (for example some of the Funds are using BARRA type analysis) but our<br>cursory review of necessity could not reveal this in detail. We would also suggest that<br>risk management become fully integrated as part of the investment management<br>process (some of the funds do this already).</p>
<p>4.7 &nbsp;&nbsp;The Funds tend to use domestic custodians (some use domestic and non-domestic<br>custodians). Although we did not have an opportunity to review this in detail, our<br>sense is that the risk and compliance services provided by custodians (the global<br>players) may be under utilised.</p>
<p>4.8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another observation for at least careful debate is whether the overall implementation<br>of tactical asset allocation overlay programs, with the notable exception of one of the<br>Funds, is necessarily appropriate given that this is an activity that requires skills that<br>are difficult to find and in which it is difficult to, consistently, add value.</p>
<p>4.9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;What is also interesting to us is that while the Funds have easily tumed to extemal<br>managers to complement their intemal expertise, this has not been the case for tactical<br>asset allocation, at least to gain an insight into some highly specialist managers are<br>doing in this area. This would seem to be the approach of some of the long standing,<br>sophisticated, in-house pension fund teams around the world, who do internal<br>modelling but benchmark their approaches with outside TAA managers as well</p>
<p>4.10 &nbsp;A similar comment as in the previous paragraph, could cover the intent expressed in<br>most instances to make more active currency bets, especially as the currency exposure<br>regulations become more liberal over time. This is also an area of quite specific<br>expertise.</p>
<p>4.11 &nbsp;&nbsp;In fact a general observation is that the Funds might be trying to do too much,<br>especially in such a short period. It is sometimes better practice to implement a few<br>steps at a time, checking the procedures and finding the flaws in periods of difficult<br>market conditions. A related point is that a number of the Funds have devised<br>structures/process on the basis of their perceived investment management strengths.<br>This is only natural, we would however urge the Funds to consider carefully the full<br>investment opportunity set and the best way of accessing this.</p>
<p>4.12 &nbsp;Those Funds which have carried out the strategy setting exercise have done so, in<br>general, thoroughly. The areas that we feel are worthy of further analysis are strategies<br>that provide for less correlated exposure to the fortunes of the Sweden economy. A<br>number of the strategies have a bias to Swedish equities on the ground of a link<br>between wage growth and the Swedish equity market, it would be interesting to<br>explore whether there is any evidence for this.</p>
<p>4.13 &nbsp;&nbsp;We would concur with an observation which was often made to us, that the Public<br>Authority status of the funds, on balance was not helpful. This touches on the<br>compensation issues mentioned above, but also the everyday regulatory burden that<br>this imposes. A particular aspect of this is the somewhat uncertain mandate of AP6<br>which in limiting its private equity investments to Sweden, might imply a social<br>responsibility to assist Swedish start-ups whatever their merits. This is being resisted,<br>as illustrated by the number of deals offered to the fund and the high number that are<br>being tumed down, but there is the perception of political sensitivities that at one point<br>might be detrimental to the performance of the fund.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>13 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4.14 It might be a good idea to introduce some economic measures of how the AP Fund<br>organisations are accomplishing their mandate. This implies the active monitoring of<br>intemal versus extemal asset management, but also the “bottom line” of the funds<br>themselves. In our experience there is no clear cut model of in-house versus total<br>outsourcing, and various combinations, as in Sweden, are generally accepted , at least<br>in the public area, like the State pension funds in the US or the generational funds<br>(ADIA, MAS, Norway Oil Fund). There has been a trend away from in-house in the<br>private sector but mostly because of focus of resources or the desire to unlock value.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>14 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 1</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Appendix A</p>
<p>Risk Warnings</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Past performance cannot be relied upon as a guide to future performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of stocks and shares, including unitised funds, can go down as well as up and<br>you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of bonds and other fixed income investments including unitised funds can go<br>down as well as up and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments denominated in a foreign currency will fluctuate with the value of the<br>currency.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of investments in real property can go down as well as up, and you may not</p>
<p>get back the amount you have invested. Valuation is generally a matter of a valuer’s<br>opinion, rather than fact. It may be difficult or impossible to realise an investment<br>because the property concemed may not be readily saleable.</p>

<p>A &nbsp;Risk Warnings</p>

<p>AP Fund 2<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Introduction</p>
<p>l. I Objective of the exercise</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance has assigned William M. Mercer Ltd to evaluate each AP<br>Fund. The objective of the assignment is to evaluate each Fund’s organisational<br>structure, and to appraise this structure in light of the mandate given it. Particular<br>focus will be placed on the risk Controls and the Fund’s ongoing compliance with the<br>objectives set by its board.</p>
<p>Our review is based on reviewing working papers and documents provided by the<br>funds, telephone conversations and an onsite visit. We would like to stress that our<br>mandate was limited to carrying out a high level review of the Funds, not a detailed<br>due diligence on the organisation and the investment policy setting.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of the AP Funds’ respective mandates</p>
<p>The First to Fourth and Sixth AP Funds have mandates to manage the buffer funds in<br>the new reformed pension system. The First and Third Fund boards has been<br>reorganised into the First AP Fund (First and Third Fund Board) and Second AP Fund<br>(Second Fund Board). As from the start of 2001, new investment rules came into force<br>for the First to Fourth AP Funds, and as result each are initially managing<br>approximately SEK 134 billion. According to legislation the First to Fourth AP Funds<br>must manage the assets in order to provide a high long-term return, satisfactory<br>liquidity, good risk diversification and a good margin of security.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of key responsibilities of Board’s</p>
<p>Each AP Fund has a team of permanent staff responsible for putting into effect the<br>decisions taken by the Fund’s governing Board.</p>
<p>The number of board members for each Fund (with the exception of the Sixth AP<br>Fund) is set to 9 members. The Government nominates all members of the board. Two<br>of the members are nominated from employer organisations and two are nominated<br>from employee organisation. The main responsibilities are to establish the Investment<br>Policy, Ownership Policy/Corporate Governance and Risk Control Plan. The board<br>can delegate responsibilities to the MD/CEO according to the Law.</p>
<p>Divyesh Hindocha</p>
<p>For and on behaif of</p>
<p>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Johan Sidenmark</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 2<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Review of organisation</p>
<p>2.1 Review of organisation</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The AP fund has currently 7 employees, with plans to move to 30-35<br>employees by the end of the year. The location in Gothenburg was both<br>political, to not appear to be too centralised, but it was also taking into account<br>the tight market in Stockholm for specialist professionals and the fact that<br>Gothenburg could be attractive for individuals looking for a change in lifestyle.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Chief Investment Officer and Chief Operating Officer, Risk Control<br>Manager and Legal Manager will all report to the CEO. The proposed<br>complete organisation of approximately 35 employees as at end 2001 is<br>illustrated in the organisation chart below:</p>
<p>Board of Directors</p>
<p>MD/CEO</p>
<p>■ ■ -</p>
<p>Public Relation</p>
<p>Investments</p>
<p>Administration '</p>
<p>I,.,</p>
<p>As6et Allocation</p>
<p>_ Equities Management<br>and Currencies</p>
<p>Interest-Bearing Assets.<br>and Currencies</p>
<p>Business Adm</p>
<p>Risk Control ;</p>
<p>...........H</p>
<p>-ii-</p>
<p>Legal Affairs</p>
<p>Accounting<br>and Finance .</p>
<p>.... . ............. . '..</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-414.png" style="width:62pt;height:48pt;"/>
<p>The organisation has two legs to it: The Investment function (headed by the CIO) and<br>the Administration function (headed by the CFO).</p>
<p>The activity of the various sub-functions are to some extent self-explanatory. The<br>main points to highlight are set out below:</p>
<p>• The Risk Control unit is responsible for daily control and reporting of risk in<br>the portfolios and expects to be involved in more risk management on a</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>prospective basis. This function also expects to control/manage operational<br>risk. The Risk Control unit reports directly to the CEO on investment issues<br>and reports to the CFO on other compliance/operational issues.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Asset Allocation unit will carry out analysis and recommendations on<br>short term asset allocation (tactical asset allocation) including currency<br>decisions. The CIO is ultimately responsible for making the tactical asset<br>allocation decision.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Altemative Investment Unit is expected to invest in Private Equity/Hedge<br>Funds.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Equity and Fixed Income teams will be responsible for managing both the<br>intemally managed assets as well as managing the extemal managers.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The CEO is responsible for the real estate.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The overall cost of running the Fund (including the fees of extemal managers),<br>defined as a percentage of the assets under management, is budgeted to be in<br>the range 12-15 basis points.</p>
<p>2.2 Management of Assets</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The interim strategy (while the organisation is built and the asset allocation<br>decision made) is to outsource all the assets. The Swedish equity exposure is<br>partly (25%) passive and partly (75%) active. The active exposure has been<br>placed with four managers. The global equities exposure is currently all<br>passively managed. The Fund uses two passive managers (Merrill Lynch<br>Investment Managers and BGI).</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The reason for selecting 4 active Swedish equity managers was to add<br>flexibility, to avoid “predictability” in the investments (essentially to avoid<br>market impact). The Fund has selected two additional “substitute” Swedish<br>equity managers in case it decides that it wishes to switch away from one of<br>the existing managers.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund had selected 6 active global equity managers and expects to fund 4<br>of them after completing the asset allocation study later this year. The other 2<br>managers are “substitutes” in case the Fund decides to switch from one of the<br>original four.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The inherited index-linked bond exposure is managed intemally on a buy and<br>hold basis.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund is in the process of determining the mix of internal and extemal<br>management, the mix between passive and active management, and in the areas<br>in which the Fund needs to hire extemal capability. The Fund expects to<br>address these questions empirically by identifying areas of likely added value<br>and how these can be accessed. Although they are at the start of this process<br>the current expectation is that the Fund will have a high proportion of the<br>assets managed by extemal managers.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In due course the Fund may consider bringing active and passive investment<br>management in-house. The passive part would only be brought in house if this<br>was deemed to be cost effective.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund wishes to have total, real time control over their total portfolio. They<br>are building a transaction database in order to re-compile performance and<br>attribution analysis. The overall risk principles are currently being written up,<br>but they are already preparing detailed weekly performance/risk reports. The<br>ambition is to move from weekly to daily (almost real time) control by<br>requesting their external managers (both active as well as passive) to send all<br>their trades real time over the Internet. They have not explored the selected<br>managers’ abilities and willingness to provide this information . The rationale<br>for this is a wish to have a clear understanding of how the individual portfolios<br>are doing, and the risks and bets being taken at the combined fund level<br>including value at risk.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Risk Control Manager has responsibility for the compliance of investment<br>restriction. The Legal Manager shall monitor and report concerning<br>compliance directly to the CEO.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Swedish active managers are currently all subject to a risk budget<br>described in tracking error terms; the tracking error target will be 3%pa. The<br>plan is to fine-tune their mandates and to impose manager specific tracking<br>errors. The tracking error targets and limits for the asset classes are yet to be<br>determined. The plan is to put these in place later this year.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund currently uses three passive managers. The stated reason for this is to<br>develop relationships with these managers with a view ultimately to perhaps<br>using enhanced indexation techniques offered by these managers.</p>
<p>2.3 Operational Issues</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The AP Fund is in the process of installing the TMS-2000 front Office system,<br>which is the dominant system for all AP funds (only one fund has a different<br>system). It is being implemented in 3 phases, first internal fund management<br>for Swedish assets by end September 2001, then extemal managers and finally<br>Middle Office. The system includes STP (Straight Through Process) and limit<br>modules, which flag investment violations.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund uses Svenska Handelsbanken as custodian bank.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 2<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2.4 People</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In order to evaluate the organisation’s strength and consistency we need to<br>define the officers’ job descriptions with emphasis on responsibilities,<br>adequacy of resources and incentives.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CEO responsibilities:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;secure that the ongoing management and activities are in compliance<br>with the law, instructions and action plans</p>
<p>implement board decisions</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;report to the board</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;operational responsibility for ownership issues</p>
<p>operational responsibility for active portfolio</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;operational responsibility for real estate issue</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;establishment of policy documents</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;performance measurement for total portfolio</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;extemal communication</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;responsibility for employees</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The MD/CEO will also take part in the&nbsp;Allocation Committee and</p>
<p>Macro Economic Meetings.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Chief Investment Officer is also the Deputy CEO and has operational<br>responsibility for the Funds management of assets. The CIO also takes final<br>decisions on asset and currency allocation and has the final decision on other<br>investment management issues. The CIO is part of the Asset Allocation<br>Committee, Equity Committee, Bond Committee and the Extemal Committees.<br>The CIO reports to the CEO. The CIO is currently on secondment from the<br>Fund’s investment advisors.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Operating Officer has overriding responsibility for all support activity and<br>all units excluding the Investment Operation.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Risk Control Manager has responsibility for ongoing control and reporting<br>to the CEO, including any violation of investment limitations.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Legal Manager is responsible for monitoring compliance according to<br>legal demands and recommendations and reports directly to the CEO.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is a significant issue to attract and retain good professionals. It would appear<br>that the base salaries offered are not too much out of line, and the work</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>environment and challenge are also attractive, but retention may be affected by<br>the current lack of a bonus programme. As part of its business plan the Fund<br>expects to have a discussion with the Board on the need to put in place an<br>incentive programme. Any plan, under civil service guidelines under which<br>they operate, will be capped at 6 months salary. We understand from press<br>statements that the Chairman of the board is unconvinced of the merits of an<br>incentive programme.</p>
<p>2.5 Mercer view</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The team appears experienced and thorough in their approach, and a good deal<br>would appear to have been accomplished since the CEO and CIO came in<br>November 2000. The AP Fund went to the trouble of visiting a number of in-<br>house managed pension schemes in the US, including General Motors and the<br>State of New York pension scheme to collect experience and to ask for advice.<br>The organisation is straight forward and has all the necessary requirements of<br>“checks and balances”.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Given that the Fund is hoping to undertake a review of the areas of added value<br>and how these should be accessed (for example the Fund may consider<br>regional mandates as one way forward) it is not clear to us why 4 global active<br>equity managers were selected at the start of the process.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The structure is also anticipating investment in alternative investments,<br>primarily private equity and hedge funds. It seems odd to us to make this part<br>of the structure before having made the strategic decision to invest in these<br>asset classes. In our view decisions to invest in these asset classes should be<br>driven on investment grounds, combined with having the resource to manage<br>these investments, and not led by the structure. Having said this, although the<br>Fund is envisaging investment in these asset classes, this decision will need to<br>be rationalised by the Alternative investments group.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The structure is a classical investment management structure, with the CIO<br>being instrumental in its design. We understand that the CIO is on secondment<br>from another organisation. One of the challenges facing the Fund will be the<br>“care and maintenance” of this structure and continuity after the CIO’s<br>secondment comes to an end.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;However, having embarked upon this course, the global equity managers<br>selected are all well known, and having a number of managers will provide<br>manager diversification. However it is not clear to us why 4 managers were<br>chosen as the optimal number, especially as, prima facie, the group as a whole<br>will probably lead to an overall growth tilt in the global equity portfolio. (The<br>Fund is conscious of this tilt which we understand was the result of the lack of<br>suitable candidates to offset this tilt).</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has appointed 4 active Swedish equity managers. The advantage of<br>this is again diversification of manager risk, however the danger is that the<br>overall portfolio is close to an indexed portfolio.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 2<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The Fund makes use of three passive managers, given the nature of passive<br>managers we do not see the rationale for this. Enhanced indexation products<br>are offered both by active as well as passive managers and we remain to be<br>convinced that an existing relationship (with a passive manager) will provide<br>the Fund with an advantage if it wishes to exploit this particular opportunity<br>set. Also we would find it difficult to envisage circumstances where the Fund<br>would find it cost effective to manage the passive assets intemally.</p>
<p>The manager selection process based on a structured score card of both<br>quantitative and qualitative criteria appears sound and well conducted given<br>the time constraints (as mentioned above we question the rationale for adopting<br>this route in advance of the strategic decisions on where and how to deploy<br>active management). Other managers for both Swedish and Global equities are<br>in the wings which is good practice in case some have to be changed at short<br>notice. We would recommend that before making any switches to the substitute<br>managers that the Fund confirms that the original conditions for the selection<br>are still in place.</p>
<p>We recommend that the transition process is thought through properly and that<br>it might be good practice to put in place some oversight of transition process.</p>
<p>The monitoring of extemal managers is largely quantitatively driven. We<br>would recommend adding a qualitative element to this. The hire and fire of<br>managers based purely on a quantitative review is, in our view, limited in its<br>effectiveness.</p>
<p>It is not clear to us why the Fund is seeking to build systems in house to have a<br>real time update on the portfolio. Building this capability is likely to be<br>resource intensive in terms of the IT and the people. This is especially the case<br>as it should be possible to obtain this information on a daily basis from a well<br>resourced custodian (for this to be effective the Fund would need to have a<br>single custodian). We would urge the Fund to explore this possibility before<br>building in-house capability in this area.</p>
<p>The combination of daily reporting and review of the managers, and the fact<br>that oversight of the extemal managers is provided by the intemal portfolio<br>managers may result in the micro-management of the extemal managers (the<br>Fund is conscious of this risk and does not intend to micro-manage the extemal<br>managers). We would also question whether in-house portfolio managers are<br>equipped to manage extemal managers, not to mention the potential for<br>distracting the intemal portfolio managers from their main focus, to manage<br>their portfolios. In practice the plan is for the Head of Equity to manage this<br>process. The Fund recognises it will not be easy to find a person with the<br>requisite skills.</p>
<p>The TMS2000 would appear quite state-of-the-art, although with some of the<br>usual deficiencies in the performance attribution area, making it necessary to<br>bolt on some additional functionalities. Apparently however, the system<br>allows for this with not too many problems.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The benefit policy is an issue that will need to be addressed not only because<br>of retention of key personnel but to create the conditions of real competition<br>between the AP Funds, which seemed to have been the intent of the legislature.<br>If there is no proper incentive along industry standards, which suggests a bonus<br>of more like 100%, there will be the temptation to manage all the funds close<br>to the peer group, even if they are not supposed to communicate among<br>themselves in that respect. After the initial secretive atmosphere of the initial<br>ALM studies and the transition steps to align portfolios, it is practically insured<br>that the market will become quite transparent in this regard. The added<br>advantage of a proper incentive plan, which could include a short-term and<br>longer-term element, is to align precisely the actions of the professionals with<br>the real objectives of the AP Funds.</p>
<p>The Board members have a relatively good experience level, and have been<br>working diligently with management meeting once a month in this start up<br>phase. The different competence levels between board members means a quite<br>extensive educational process is performed by the AP Fund. The key to be able<br>to keep the balance between professional members and members with other<br>experiences appears to inställ some continuity by extending the mandates<br>beyond one year and not to shift all members at the same time. It is also worth<br>considering whether existing compensation to the Board members is enough to<br>truly motivate them.</p>
<p>This is still very much work in progress, but the team conveys a strong sense of<br>competence and thoroughness in its approach.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 2<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 ALM</p>
<p>3.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has not as yet carried out an ALM study. Therefore this report does not</p>
<p>address this issue. The Fund has started developing its thinking in this area and hopes<br>to be in a position to have made its decision over the next few months. We understand<br>that the strategy is going to be based on the Fund’s interpretation of the objectives of<br>the buffer fund system, and not on competitive grounds (ie on the basis of the<br>decisions made by the other AP Funds).</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4 Overall Assessment</p>
<p>4.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section is intended to be an overall assessment based on our discussions with all<br>the Funds. Some of the points are more relevant to some Funds and less to others.</p>
<p>4.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have been impressed by the overall quality, experience and motivation of the<br>professionals that we met. Hard work has accomplished a great deal in a relatively<br>short time span, either to create a totally new organisation or to undertake a major re-<br>structuring of existing funds.</p>
<p>4.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In spite of new Board of Directors that include a varying proportion of non-initiated<br>people, they have also clearly risen to the challenge and have worked diligently with<br>management to set the framework for operating the system. To ensure their continuing<br>support, and although we understand the spirit of public service in Sweden, we wonder<br>if their remuneration could not be raised from the current SKr. 50,000 p.a.</p>
<p>4.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;We have the same kind of concerns regarding the compensation of the fund<br>professionals. While we can understand the attraction of the challenge of these new<br>funds for investment professionals, with the focus on hands on investment<br>management and an absence of bureaucracy compared with the mega-fmancial<br>institutions of today, at one point money does talk. Our concern is mostly on the bonus<br>side where the 6 months salary cap is clearly not in line with industry practice.<br>Personnel retention may become a real issue, especially as other third party managers<br>will come to view these people as providing an entry point into these funds. Although<br>we must emphasise that we have in no way detected this, it might be natural for<br>investment professionals to view a couple of years at an AP Fund in the same light and<br>good on a resumé. This is some thing we have observed with the investment teams of<br>Central Banks or Generational Funds. If this were to occur, it would clearly be<br>detrimental to the long term performance of the Funds.</p>
<p>4.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another aspect to this, is that it seem to us that the intent of the legislator in setting up<br>these competing funds was to generate a healthy competition to boost the overall risk<br>adjusted return of the buffer fund system. This would be better accomplished by a<br>clear linkage between value creation and remuneration, including short and longer<br>term incentives. The opposite risk in the absence of this linkage is that all the funds<br>will basically revert over time to a peer group average.</p>
<p>4.6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have found all the funds to place risk control at the forefront of their concerns<br>which is clearly within their mandate. By and large this is monitored in an appropriate<br>fashion in terms of its independence from investment management, reporting lines to<br>the CEO/Board and the type of reports. The only fundamental observation for possible<br>review, is that risk management cannot be condensed into one statistic, notably<br>tracking error, but must be reviewed in multiple cuts to understand the type of risk the<br>overall fund is taking and whether these are consistent with the house view or among<br>the various internal/external mandates. We suspect that for the most part this is being</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>10 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>done, (for example some of the Funds are using BARRA type analysis) but our<br>cursory review of necessity could not reveal this in detail. We would also suggest that<br>risk management become fully integrated as part of the investment management<br>process (some of the funds do this already).</p>
<p>4.7 &nbsp;&nbsp;The Funds tend to use domestic custodians (some use domestic and non-domestic<br>custodians). Although we did not have an opportunity to review this in detail, our<br>sense is that the risk and compliance services provided by custodians (the global<br>players) may be under utilised.</p>
<p>4.8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another observation for at least careful debate is whether the overall implementation<br>of tactical asset allocation overlay programs, with the notable exception of one of the<br>Funds, is necessarily appropriate given that this is an activity that requires skills that<br>are difficult to find and in which it is difficult to, consistently, add value.</p>
<p>4.9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;What is also interesting to us is that while the Funds have easily tumed to extemal<br>managers to complement their intemal expertise, this has not been the case for tactical<br>asset allocation, at least to gain an insight into some highly specialist managers are<br>doing in this area. This would seem to be the approach of some of the long standing,<br>sophisticated, in-house pension fund teams around the world, who do intemal<br>modelling but benchmark their approaches with outside TAA managers as well</p>
<p>4.10 &nbsp;A similar comment as in the previous paragraph, could cover the intent expressed in<br>most instances to make more active currency bets, especially as the currency exposure<br>regulations become more liberal over time. This is also an area of quite specific<br>expertise.</p>
<p>4.11 &nbsp;&nbsp;In fact a general observation is that the Funds might be trying to do too much,<br>especially in such a short period. It is sometimes better practice to implement a few<br>steps at a time, checking the procedures and finding the flaws in periods of difficult<br>market conditions. A related point is that a number of the Funds have devised<br>structures/process on the basis of their perceived investment management strengths.<br>This is only natural, we would however urge the Funds to consider carefully the full<br>investment opportunity set and the best way of accessing this.</p>
<p>4.12 &nbsp;Those Funds which have carried out the strategy setting exercise have done so, in<br>general, thoroughly. The areas that we feel are worthy of further analysis are strategies<br>that provide for less correlated exposure to the fortunes of the Sweden economy. A<br>number of the strategies have a bias to Swedish equities on the ground of a link<br>between wage growth and the Swedish equity market, it would be interesting to<br>explore whether there is any evidence for this.</p>
<p>4.13 &nbsp;We would concur with an observation which was often made to us, that the Public<br>Authority status of the funds, on balance was not helpful. This touches on the<br>compensation issues mentioned above, but also the everyday regulatory burden that<br>this imposes. A particular aspect of this is the somewhat uncertain mandate of AP6<br>which in limiting its private equity investments to Sweden, might imply a social<br>responsibility to assist Swedish start-ups whatever their merits. This is being resisted,<br>as illustrated by the number of deals offered to the fund and the high number that are<br>being tumed down, but there is the perception of political sensitivities that at one point<br>might be detrimental to the performance of the fund.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>11 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4.14 It might be a good idea to introduce some economic measures of how the AP Fund<br>organisations are accomplishing their mandate. This implies the active monitoring of<br>internal versus external asset management, but also the “bottom line” of the funds<br>themselves. In our experience there is no clear cut model of in-house versus total<br>outsourcing, and various combinations, as in Sweden, are generally accepted , at least<br>in the public area, like the State pension funds in the US or the generational funds<br>(ADIA, MAS, Norway Oil Fund). There has been a trend away from in-house in the<br>private sector but mostly because of focus of resources or the desire to unlock value.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>12 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 2</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Appendix A</p>
<p>Risk Warnings</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Past performance cannot be relied upon as a guide to future performance.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;The value of stocks and shares, including unitised funds, can go down as well as up and<br>you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;The value of bonds and other fixed income investments including unitised funds can go<br>down as well as up and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Investments denominated in a foreign currency will fluctuate with the value of the<br>currency.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;The value of investments in real property can go down as well as up, and you may not get<br>back the amount you have invested. Valuation is generally a matter of a valuer’s opinion,<br>rather than fact. It may be difficult or impossible to realise an investment because the<br>property concerned may not be readily saleable.</p>
