<p>A &nbsp;Risk Warnings</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 3<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Introdiiction</p>
<p>l. I Objective of evaluation</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance has commissioned William M. Mercer Ltd to evaluate each<br>AP Fund. The objective of the assignment is to evaluate each Fund’s organisational<br>structure in light of the mandate it has been given. Particular focus will be placed on<br>the risk Controls and the Fund’s ongoing compliance with the objectives set by its<br>Board. The evaluation of the Investment Policy will cover overall methodology,<br>objectives and assumptions used when performing the Asset Liability Study.</p>
<p>Our review has been based on a review of working papers and documents provided by<br>the Funds, telephone conversations and an onsite visit. We would like to stress that our<br>mandate was limited to carrying out a high level review of the Funds, and not a<br>detailed due diligence of the organisation and the investment policy setting.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of the AP Funds’ respective mandates</p>
<p>The First to Fourth and Sixth AP Funds have mandates to manage the buffer funds in<br>the new reformed pension system. As from the start of 2001, new investment rules<br>came into force for the First to Fourth AP Funds, and as result each are initially<br>managing approximately SEK 134 billion. According to legislation, the First to Fourth<br>AP Funds must manage the assets in order to provide a high long-term return,<br>satisfactory liquidity, good risk diversification and a good margin of security.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of key responsibilities of each AP Fund Board</p>
<p>Each AP Fund has a team of permanent staff responsible for putting into effect the<br>decisions taken by the Fund’s goveming Board.</p>
<p>The number of Board members for each Fund (with the exception of the Sixth AP<br>Fund) is set to 9 members. The Government nominates all members of each Board.<br>Two of these members are nominated from employer organisations and two are<br>nominated from employee organisations. The Board’s main responsibilities are to<br>establish the investment policy, govemance policy and Risk Control Plan for the Fund<br>in question. The Board can delegate responsibilities to the MD/CEO according to the<br>law.</p>
<p>Stephen Woodcock</p>
<p>For and on behaif of</p>
<p>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Johan Sidenmark</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 3<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Review of organisation</p>
<p>2.1 Organisational Structure</p>
<p>The organisation is divided into three business units (the Intemal Equity team, Intemal<br>Bond and Currency team and the External Management team) and a Business<br>Administration team. Both the Internal Equity and Intemal Bond and Currency teams<br>include traders. In addition there is a Quantitative Research team responsible for<br>asset/Iiability modelling, risk control and performance measurement. The aim has<br>been to create a flat organisational structure with a team focus. The CEO and the<br>Deputy CEO work in both multiple and overlapping roles. The Intemal Equities team<br>reports directly to the CEO. The CEO is directly involved in the management of<br>assets with particularly close involvement in the domestic equity portfolio. The<br>Intemal Bond and Currency team, the Quantitative Research team and the Extemal<br>Management team report to the Chief Investment Officer who is also the Deputy CEO.<br>The business administration team reports to the Chief Operating' Officer. The<br>organisational chart below illustrates personnel reporting lines and some of the<br>functional responsibilities as at the start of 2001.</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-415.png" style="width:296pt;height:191pt;"/>
<p>This structure was largely put in place over 1999 and 2000. The Fund brought in a<br>consultant to advise them on organisational matters in 1999. At the start of the re-<br>organisational process, the Fund tried to establish a “corporate” philosophy. A<br>number of key themes were identified as follows:</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 3<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Professionalism.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Focus: the Fund should identify the areas in which it can genuinely expect to add<br>value. Tasks should only be performed intemally if suitable skills exist. In<br>other areas the Fund should be prepared to outsource to extemal firms.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Continuous development of both employees and the organisation.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A team-based structure: each staff member should be trusted to accept<br>responsibility and it should be clear that each member’s contribution is valued.<br>Work undertaken should be freely available to other staff.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Openness within the organisation: staff to be involved in the decision-making<br>process and trusted with confidential information. This also to extend<br>extemally, except where information is market-sensitive.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Enjoyment.</p>
<p>2.2 Management of Assets</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The philosophy of the organisation is to take risk only where it can be expected<br>to add value, and to apportion assets intemally or extemally according to<br>competence.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s investment process is team driven and is only partly captured by the<br>organisational chart describing the personnel reporting lines. The following chart<br>describes to investment decision-making structure:</p>
<p>Chief Investment Officer :</p>
<p>Niklas Ekvall</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-416.png" style="width:288pt;height:120pt;"/>
<p>The establishment of investment policy begins with the Fund’s Board. Based on<br>advice from the CEO, CIO and the ALM/Risk team, they reach a decision on the<br>Fund’s strategic or benchmark portfolio. The Board is then also responsible for<br>setting parameters and restrictions for the management of the Fund’s assets<br>relative to the strategic portfolio. In particular they consider the extent to which<br>risk may be accepted relative to the benchmark in pursuit of additional value.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The CIO then allocates the allowable “risk budget” to the different areas of the<br>organisation responsible for implementation.</p>
<p>An interim team takes responsibility for tactical asset allocation, although this<br>area is under review; there are separate intemal equity and bond teams; and there<br>is a team responsible for the appointment and monitoring of extemal investment<br>managers for areas of the strategic portfolio not covered by the intemal equity<br>and bond teams. Extemal managers are used where the relevant competence is<br>judged not to exist intemally.</p>
<p>The Fund is judged to have sufficient competencies in Swedish and European<br>Equities and sovereign debt (Sweden, Euro, UK, Japan, US) plus high quality<br>credit. At present, all extemal mandates are passively managed. The team<br>responsible for extemal managers will try to identify those areas where active<br>management could be expected to work. The use of extemal active management<br>appears likely in due course for more areas of the Fund’s strategic benchmark.</p>
<p>The average experience level for members of the Intemal Equity and the Bond<br>&amp; Currency teams is 14 years, and for the Traders is 16 years.</p>
<p>The structure for risk control/monitoring is defined in the Risk Control Plan. The<br>Chief Investment Officer is responsible for risk management/budgeting and is<br>monitored by the Compliance Officer who reports directly to the Board. The<br>Fund uses an independent consultant (Deloitte &amp; Touche) for performance<br>evaluation and the auditors (KPMG and PwC) provide the Board with reports.</p>
<p>The strategic or benchmark portfolio is defined by the ALM. In the long-run,<br>the goal is to out-perform the strategic portfolio with an information ratio of 0.2.<br>The tracking error should not exceed 4%. Over 2001, interim arrangements are<br>in place... (sekretessbelagt). The outperformance target for 2001 is 0.3%.</p>
<p>Swedish equities are managed actively. The equity team also covers around 10<br>sectors within European markets and these are managed actively with the other<br>sectors managed passively. The decision on which sectors to manage actively is<br>in part a reflection of the existing skills within the team and in part a judgement<br>on the capacity to add value within different sectors (some being regarded as<br>driven by factors beyond the scope of the team to predict, such as the oil price).<br>The equity team currently numbers 10, including the CEO and the CIO who both<br>have responsibilities as sector managers. The team also includes two traders<br>who perform sector manager tasks. The team is supported by a quantitative<br>analyst and a part-time macro analyst.</p>
<p>The bond team numbers 7 people at present. In addition to the team leader,<br>there is one portfolio manager focusing on sovereign debt (Sweden, Euro, UK,<br>US and Japan) and one on credit, three traders who also provide back-up to the<br>portfolio managers and a quantitative analyst.</p>
<p>The Fund has 3 employees for hiring and monitoring external managers.<br>Tendering for mandates will be done in accordance to standard procedures for<br>placement of Government contracts. Having received tenders, the Extemal<br>Manager team will make a proposal. The CEO and CIO will jointly make the</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 3<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>final decision on the appointment of the extemal manager. The Extemal<br>Managers team will use consultants for peer review and data provision.</p>
<p>At present the bulk of the risk budget is allocated to the intemal equity team.<br>All extemal management is, for the moment, passive, and the bond team is<br>relatively new. (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>Risk management reports come from the Business Administration team, under<br>the Chief Operating Officer, from the custodian, Northern Trust, and from a<br>separate outside provider, MPIR, affiliated with Deloitte. Northern Trust also<br>enables the Fund to constantly monitor its overall currency exposure, which is<br>partially hedged in-line with current regulations covering the AP Funds. More<br>active currency bets may be taken in the future.</p>
<p>According to the new investment rules, extemal managers will manage a least<br>10% of the Fund’s assets. Extemal managers (State Street and Merrill Lynch)<br>have been retained for passive management at present, including US, Japan and<br>European equities. Active mandates are now being considered.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Operational</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund uses Northern Trust Company as custodian bank.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has invested in a new IT system for both the Investment Organisation<br>and its Business Administration. They have settled on Advent, which they tell us<br>is working well. They note that although TMS 2000 has been adopted by the<br>other funds, it would appear to them that it is costly in its implementation,<br>having a greater need for support staff. Advent is basically a portfolio<br>administration system and does lack risk analytical functions. For this reason,<br>they have also added BARRA.</p>
<p>2.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;People</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In order to evaluate the organisation’s strength and consistency we need to<br>define the officers’ job descriptions with emphasis on responsibilities, adequacy<br>of resources and incentives.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Board takes responsibility for the following:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;deciding the strategic asset allocation (the benchmark)</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;appointing and determining compensation for CEO</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ensuring that the Fund’s activity is conducted according to the applicable<br>legislation</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;deciding investment objectives in accordance with the applicable<br>legislation</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;report to the government according to the applicable legislation</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CEO responsibilities:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;secure that the ongoing management and activities are in compliance with<br>the law, instructions and action plans</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;implement Board decisions</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;report to the Board</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;recruit and determine compensation for&nbsp;employees</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;secure compliance with Board instructions and action plans</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;acceptance of all responsibilities delegated by the Board</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Deputy CEO is also the Chief Investment Officer with responsibility for<br>risk management/budgeting.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Compliance Manager is responsible for monitoring risk and compliance and<br>reports directly to the Board of Directors.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since 1998, the Fund has had an incentive program for all its employees, with<br>the exception of the Compliance Manager. In 2000, the incentive program was<br>revised to reflect the Fund’s new mandate. The objective has been to link the<br>Fund’s recruitment and retention.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The incentive program is linked to five objectives, four of which are linked to<br>the Fund’s investment performance and one to the individuaFs performance.<br>The incentive program is consistent with guidelines covering employees in state-<br>owned companies.</p>
<p>2.5 Mercer overall view</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The organisational structure and philosophy makes sense. The two key<br>individuals have complementary strengths (equity/fixed income) and the<br>organisation is in effect structured around this. In this respect it is not a<br>conventional structure and problems may arise if either left the organisation for<br>whatever reason. As an illustration, the intemal equity team does not report to<br>the CIO but directly to the CEO, albeit that the CIO still retains responsibility<br>for risk management over all the investment teams.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The relatively small size of the organisation permits a flat structure and allows<br>the senior staff to disseminate information across the teams without difficulty.<br>As we have not met the great majority of the staff, we cannot comment on<br>whether the culture meets the original aims when the structure was designed.<br>We see no reason, however, why it should not.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The upfront emphasis on the need to establish a strong culture for the Fund<br>shows a good understanding of one of the most important criteria for success in<br>asset management. The choice of another system than TMS 2000, would appear<br>to indicate an independence of view which is not unwelcome. The only potential<br>concem, which is common to many of the AP Funds, is the ambition to<br>accomplish so much at once: intemal management, extemal management,<br>numerous asset classes, TAA, currency overlay etc.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The approach to intemal investment management is complex but well thought<br>out in terms of a logical series of decision points and a systematic challenge<br>system. A decision in principal has been taken... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One relatively unique feature of this Fund is a dedicated team of three, with the<br>support of the quant team, to monitor the extemal managers. In other Funds it is<br>a combination of the intemal managers and management who accomplish this<br>function. In our view, the Fund’s approach has certain advantages in terms of<br>monitoring extemal managers and reacting appropriately to any slippage in risk<br>adjusted performance.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As we have not met the intemal investment teams themselves, we are not in a<br>position to comment on their effectiveness and therefore the extent to which they<br>might be expected to add value in comparison to either a passive or active<br>external alternative.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>As with other AP Funds, there is a question in our minds over the extent to<br>which the Fund will be prepared to respond to sustained underperformance by its<br>intemal teams. Any radical response might be particularly divisive, especially in<br>the context of an organisation whose culture is designed to be open and<br>inclusive.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 ALM</p>
<p>3.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Introduction</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s investment strategy was determined with the assistance of an<br>asset/liability modelling exercise conducted jointly with Watson Wyatt during<br>2000, using demographic scenario data provided by the National Social<br>Insurance Board (“RFV”).</p>
<p>3.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Objectives</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund concluded that identifying a single objective by which to measure<br>different investment policies and thereby to set investment strategy was not<br>possible. Instead, several variables were considered describing both the overall<br>State pension system as well as the buffer fund system:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The measure used to describe the broader State system was termed the<br>“System Surplus”, defined as the sum of Contribution Capital and the<br>Buffer Funds less the Pensions Debt.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To describe the buffer funds themselves, a “brake” measure was used in<br>the form of the ratio of the Balance Index to the Income Index; net cash<br>flows relative to the size of the Fund were also modelled; and Fund<br>strength was modelled, being the number of years’ pension payments that<br>the buffer funds could meet on a stand-alone basis.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As the Fund had no data on the strategic policies of the other AP Funds, it was<br>not possible to model it in isolation. It was instead necessary to model the<br>buffer funds as a group and assume that they behaved in a similar fashion.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The year 2024 was identified as providing a suitable projection period. This was<br>favoured because it represented a long-term assessment that included a period of<br>expected strain to the buffer funds (when cashflow is expected to be negative).<br>Analysis of projections to other dates was also carried out.</p>
<p>3.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Methodology/Assumptions</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Apart from the difficuity in identifying a single objective against which to<br>optimise investment strategy, the complexity of a pure optimisation process,<br>even on the basis of a limited asset/liability linkage, was a further constraint. In<br>consequence, the asset/liability modelling process was conducted in two stages.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;First, an asset-only optimisation was conducted using mean/variance analysis on<br>real returns. This was used to identify 10 portfolios representing a wide<br>risk/return range and which conformed to both the formal investment constraints</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>imposed on the buffer funds together with a number of additional constraints<br>identified by the Fund itself.</p>
<p>To these 10, a number of other portfolios were added for consideration in the<br>second stage, including the initial portfolio (the expected distribution of the<br>portfolio to be received at 31 December 2000).</p>
<p>In the second stage, a range of measures (including those identified above) were<br>then modelled under each of the portfolios and tested in terms of both expected<br>development and risk. Risk was quantified in terms of a “worst case” outcome<br>taken to be the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile (in other words, 95% of outcomes are expected to<br>be better than the worst case).</p>
<p>The asset model used was the Wilkie model.</p>
<p>Assets were divided into the following classes: Swedish equity, European (ex<br>Sweden) equity, global (ex Europé) equity, Swedish fixed income bonds, global<br>(ex Sweden) fixed income bonds, Swedish inflation-linked bonds, real estate and<br>cash.</p>
<p>Return assumptions for the different asset classes were based on a survey of<br>forecasts from 5 different organisations, with the final assumptions used being<br>close to the average in each asset class. Domestic Swedish equities were<br>assumed to have higher expected returns than international markets (risk was<br>also assumed to be higher to ensure a consistent risk/reward balance).</p>
<p>Modelling of asset returns, price inflation and wage inflation were the only<br>stochastic elements of the projections. All demographic elements (apart from<br>inflation) were projected deterministically, based on the RFV projections. The<br>main analysis was undertaken on the central (or “base case”) RFV projection.</p>
<p>The capacity did not exist to model all factors relevant to the inter-relationship<br>of assets and liabilities beyond price and wage inflation. For example, while a<br>Swedish recession might reasonably be expected to have an impact on<br>Contribution Capital, Pensions Debt and the assets of the buffer funds, the<br>dynamics of such a link were unknown. Even so, an attempt was made to tie<br>different asset assumptions to liability scenarios within the stress testing analysis<br>(mentioned below).</p>
<p>Projections were made on the base case RFV demographic scenario plus a<br>further four scenarios. Each of these five scenarios was considered on three<br>bases for labour force participation. In other words, a total of 15 demographic<br>scenarios were considered.</p>
<p>In addition, the central asset class return assumptions were adjusted to produce a<br>further 7 sets of assumptions for stress testing purposes.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>10 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Analysis of Results</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The first stage of modelling produced 10 portfolios... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The second stage concluded... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The study suggested that diversification of equity exposure away from Sweden,<br>on a partially currency hedged basis, was advantageous.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;More modest holdings of Swedish real estate and cash were found to have risk<br>reduction benefits and found a place in low risk portfolios.</p>
<p>3.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;Mercer View</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s strategic analysis has been detailed, however as with all the AP<br>Funds, the process was to a certain extent hampered by uncertainty as to the<br>investment objectives.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is seldom possible to say defmitively that an investment strategy decision is<br>incorrect as it is a judgement entirely dependent upon risk tolerance and the need<br>to accept risk. Very high equity weightings could be justified in the context of<br>the AP Funds as could very low weightings. No real guidance is given to the AP<br>Funds in quantitative terms on the acceptable level of risk in the context of the<br>broader State pension system. The need to compete with other AP Funds<br>naturally drives funds towards high equity weightings, although such<br>considerations were not necessarily explicitly factored in to the Fund’s analysis.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Third Fund... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The analysis resulting from the ALM does appear to justify the strategic decision<br>taken. Certain assumptions were stress-tested in reaching the conclusion.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;However our mandate does not extend to replicating the modelling process<br>ourselves and so it is not possible to draw firm conclusions on the reliability of<br>the analysis. The model used is widely (although certainly not universally)<br>accepted and the work was carried out by a reputable firm . While our analysis<br>might have yielded different results, this would most likely be driven by more<br>subjective judgements on the mechanics of markets and so would not, of itself,<br>invalidate the analysis used by the Fund.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The most prominent deficiency in the ALM process, and one that all the Funds<br>faced, was effectively modelling a link between assets and liabilities beyond<br>purely inflation. It is this area in which we believe risk is most likely to be<br>understated. A link between recession, reduced contribution income and poor<br>equity returns is highly plausible and it is precisely this sort of scenario that will<br>adversely affect an equity-biased AP Fund to a potentially substantial degree.<br>More work needs to be undertaken in this area. In fairness to the Fund, they are<br>well aware of this and have identified it as an area for further research in the<br>future. Their analysis did make some attempt to introduce a link within their<br>scenarios.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>11 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The decision to... (sekretessbelagt) makes intuitive sense from a risk<br>diversification perspective. We are less comfortable with the allocation to non-<br>Swedish government bonds, even on a currency-hedged basis. In our view,<br>Swedish inflation-linked bonds are the least risk asset for the AP Fund’s<br>liabilities. Liquidity is, of course, a constraint on substantial exposure to these<br>assets.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>12 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4 Overall Assessment</p>
<p>4.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section is intended to be an overall assessment based on our discussions with all<br>the Funds. Some of the points are more relevant to some Funds and less to others.</p>
<p>4.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have been impressed by the overall quality, experience and motivation of the<br>professionals that we met. Hard work has accomplished a great deal in a relatively<br>short time span, either to create a totally new organisation or to undertake a major re-<br>structuring of existing funds.</p>
<p>4.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In spite of new Board of Directors that include a varying proportion of non-initiated<br>people, they have also clearly risen to the challenge and have worked diligently with<br>management to set the framework for operating the system. To ensure their continuing<br>support, and although we understand the spirit of public service in Sweden, we wonder<br>if their remuneration could not be raised from the current SKr. 50,000 p.a.</p>
<p>4.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;We have the same kind of concerns regarding the compensation of the fund<br>professionals. While we can understand the attraction of the challenge of these new<br>funds for investment professionals, with the focus on hands on investment<br>management and an absence of bureaucracy compared with the mega-financial<br>institutions of today, at one point money does talk. Our concem is mostly on the bonus<br>side where the 6 months salary cap is clearly not in line with industry practice.<br>Personnel retention may become a real issue, especially as other third party managers<br>will come to view these people as providing an entry point into these funds. Although<br>we must emphasise that we have in no way detected this, it might be natural for<br>investment professionals to view a couple of years at an AP Fund in the same light and<br>good on a resumé. This is some thing we have observed with the investment teams of<br>Central Banks or Generational Funds. If this were to occur, it would clearly be<br>detrimental to the long term performance of the Funds.</p>
<p>4.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another aspect to this, is that it seem to us that the intent of the legislator in setting up<br>these competing funds was to generate a healthy competition to boost the overall risk<br>adjusted return of the buffer fund system. This would be better accomplished by a<br>clear linkage between value creation and remuneration, including short and longer<br>term incentives. The opposite risk in the absence of this linkage is that all the funds<br>will basically revert over time to a peer group average.</p>
<p>4.6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have found all the funds to place risk control at the forefront of their concerns<br>which is clearly within their mandate. By and large this is monitored in an appropriate<br>fashion in terms of its independence from investment management, reporting lines to<br>the CEO/Board and the type of reports. The only fundamental observation for possible<br>review, is that risk management cannot be condensed into one statistic, notably<br>tracking error, but must be reviewed in multiple cuts to understand the type of risk the<br>overall fund is taking and whether these are consistent with the house view or among<br>the various intemal/extemal mandates. We suspect that for the most part this is being</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>13 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>done, (for example some of the Funds are using BARRA type analysis) but our<br>cursory review of necessity could not reveal this in detail. We would also suggest that<br>risk management become fully integrated as part of the investment management<br>process (some of the funds do this already).</p>
<p>4.7 &nbsp;&nbsp;The Funds tend to use domestic custodians (some use domestic and non-domestic<br>custodians). Although we did not have an opportunity to review this in detail, our<br>sense is that the risk and compliance services provided by custodians (the global<br>players) may be under utilised.</p>
<p>4.8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another observation for at least caréful debate is whether the overall implementation<br>of tactical asset allocation overlay programs, with the notable exception of one of the<br>Funds, is necessarily appropriate given that this is an activity that requires skills that<br>are difficult to find and in which it is difficult to, consistently, add value.</p>
<p>4.9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;What is also interesting to us is that while the Funds have easily turned to extemal<br>managers to complement their internal expertise, this has not been the case for tactical<br>asset allocation, at least to gain an insight into some highly specialist managers are<br>doing in this area. This would seem to be the approach of some of the long standing,<br>sophisticated, in-house pension fund teams around the world, who do internal<br>modelling but benchmark their approaches with outside TAA managers as well</p>
<p>4.10 &nbsp;A similar comment as in the previous paragraph, could cover the intent expressed in<br>most instances to make more active currency bets, especially as the currency exposure<br>regulations become more liberal over time. This is also an area of quite specific<br>expertise.</p>
<p>4.11 &nbsp;&nbsp;In fact a general observation is that the Funds might be trying to do too much,<br>especially in such a short period. It is sometimes better practice to implement a few<br>steps at a time, checking the procedures and finding the flaws in periods of difficult<br>market conditions. A related point is that a number of the Funds have devised<br>structures/process on the basis of their perceived investment management strengths.<br>This is only natural, we would however urge the Funds to consider carefully the full<br>investment opportunity set and the best way of accessing this.</p>
<p>4.12 &nbsp;Those Funds which have carried out the strategy setting exercise have done so, in<br>general, thoroughly. The areas that we feel are worthy of further analysis are strategies<br>that provide for less correlated exposure to the fortunes of the Sweden economy. A<br>number of the strategies have a bias to Swedish equities on the ground of a link<br>between wage growth and the Swedish equity market, it would be interesting to<br>explore whether there is any evidence for this.</p>
<p>4.13 &nbsp;We would concur with an observation which was often made to us, that the Public<br>Authority status of the funds, on balance was not helpful. This touches on the<br>compensation issues mentioned above, but also the everyday regulatory burden that<br>this imposes. A particular aspect of this is the somewhat uncertain mandate of AP6<br>which in limiting its private equity investments to Sweden, might imply a social<br>responsibility to assist Swedish start-ups whatever their merits. This is being resisted,<br>as illustrated by the number of deals offered to the fund and the high number that are<br>being turned down, but there is the perception of political sensitivities that at one point<br>might be detrimental to the performance of the fund.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>14 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4.14 It might be a good idea to introduce some economic measures of how the AP Fund<br>organisations are accomplishing their mandate. This implies the active monitoring of<br>intemal versus extemal asset management, but also the “bottom line” of the funds<br>themselves. In our experience there is no clear cut model of in-house versus total<br>outsourcing, and various combinations, as in Sweden, are generally accepted , at least<br>in the public area, like the State pension funds in the US or the generational funds<br>(ADIA, MAS, Norway Oil Fund). There has been a trend away from in-house in the<br>private sector but mostly because of focus of resources or the desire to unlock value.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>15 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 3</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Appendix A</p>
<p>Risk Warnings</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Past performance cannot be relied upon as a guide to future performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of stocks and shares, including unitised funds, can go down as well as up<br>and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of bonds and other fixed income investments including unitised funds can<br>go down as well as up and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments denominated in a foreign currency will fluctuate with the value of the<br>currency.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of investments in real property can go down as well as up, and you may not<br>get back the amount you have invested. Valuation is generally a matter of a valuer’s<br>opinion, rather than fact. It may be difficult or impossible to realise an investment<br>because the property concemed may not be readily saleable.</p>

<p>A &nbsp;Risk Warnings</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Introduction</p>
<p>1.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Objective of evaluation</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance has assigned William M. Mercer Ltd to evaluate each AP<br>Fund. The objective of the assignment is to evaluate each Fund’s organisational<br>structure, and to appraise this structure in light of the mandate given it. Particular<br>focus will be placed on the risk Controls and the Fund’s ongoing compliance with the<br>objectives set by its board. The evaluation of the Investment Policy will cover overall<br>methodology, objectives and assumptions used when performing the Asset Liability<br>Study.</p>
<p>Our review is based on reviewing working papers and documents provided by the<br>Funds, telephone conversations and an onsite visit. We would like to stress that our<br>mandate was limited to carrying out a high level review of the Funds, and not a<br>detailed due diligence of the organisation and the investment policy setting.</p>
<p>Summary of the AP Funds’ respective mandates</p>
<p>The First to Fourth and Sixth AP Funds have mandates to manage the buffer funds in<br>the new reformed pension system. As from the start of 2001, new investment rules<br>came into force for the First to Fourth AP Funds, and as result each are initially<br>managing approximately SEK 134 billion. According to legislation the First to Fourth<br>AP Funds must manage the assets in order to provide a high long-term return,<br>satisfactory liquidity, good risk diversification and a good margin of security.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of key responsibilities of the Board</p>
<p>Each AP Fund has a team of permanent staff responsible for putting into effect the<br>decisions taken by the Fund’s goveming Board.</p>
<p>The number of board members for each Fund (with the exception of the Sixth AP<br>Fund) is set to 9 members. The Government nominates all members of the board. Two<br>of the members are nominated from employer organisations and two are nominated<br>from employee organisations. The main responsibilities are to establish the Investment<br>Policy, Ownership Policy/Corporate Govemance and Risk Control Plan. The board<br>can delegate responsibilities to the MD/CEO according to the Law.</p>
<p>Divyesh Hindocha</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Johan Sidenmark</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Review of organisation</p>
<p>2.1 Overall organisation</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has decided to create an organisation with defined roles,<br>responsibilities and investment limits for both teams and individual. The Board<br>of Directors decides the “Goal and Instructions”, Ownership Policy and Risk<br>Control Plan. The CEO has overriding responsibility for limits, new products<br>and markets and larger investments.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Chief Investment Officer has responsibility for investment in quoted<br>Equities and bonds. The Equity Team has responsibility for investment in<br>Swedish and Global Equities, and the Bond Team have responsibility for Bond<br>investment and currency. The Finance Analysis/Sector Analysis Team will<br>analyse individual companies (on a sector basis as far as possible) and the<br>Portfolio Analysis Team will have responsibility for macro, portfolio and<br>quantitative analyses.</p>
<p>* The Deputy CEO has responsibility for unquoted Equities and the Chief<br>Operating Officer for business administration. The Business and Risk Control<br>Unit has responsibility for the Fund rules concerning risk, monitoring and risk<br>control. The risk control unit reports to the CEO.</p>
<p>The Chief Investment Officer and Director of Administration, Risk Control<br>Unit, will report to the CEO'. The complete organisation of approximately 33<br>employees as at 2001 is illustrated in the organisation chart below:</p>
<p>Board of Oirectors</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-417.png" style="width:270pt;height:94pt;"/>
<p>_ • &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PorffoBo Analysis <sup>:</sup></p>
<p>- Frarco Amlys s / Sector Manasemeri</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-418.png" style="width:96pt;height:14pt;"/><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-419.png" style="width:93pt;height:40pt;"/>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2.2 Management of assets</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The philosophy is to achieve the optimal mix between active and passive,<br>intemal and extemal management. The investment process shall be disciplined<br>and based on fundamental analysis that is complemented with quantitative<br>analysis.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has developed a sound understanding of the relationship between<br>risk required to obtain a certain retum target. A Portfolio Analysis team<br>provides rigorous analysis (“decision support”) for the CIO and the investment<br>teams.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has an annual process to establish investment philosophy. The<br>starting point is the ALM (Asset Liability Model) that defines the strategic<br>portfolio/normal portfolio in compliance with regulatory restrictions . (It is<br>interesting to note that the Fund has gone to some lengths to interpret the<br>legislation). The strategic portfolio forms the basis for measuring performance<br>and risk.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has a Finance Committee, which provides support to the CEO on<br>risk considerations . The Finance Committee provides the CEO with the input<br>required to set the risk budget for the CIO (ie for the investment process). The<br>risk mandates are prepared and decided in compliance with the “Goal and<br>Instruction” document established by the Board of Directors. The Finance<br>Committee also suggests changes in the policy document like the “Goal and<br>Instruction” document and “Risk Control Plan”. Annually, the Finance<br>Committee will also evaluate the Investment Process and the ALM.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Business and Risk Control Unit has responsibility for the compliance of<br>investment restriction and shall monitor and report directly to the CEO The<br>risk parameters and investment restrictions set by Board shall control the<br>Fund’s activities. There is an overall fund Tracking Error of 4%.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Finance Committee provides the recommendations to the Board on the<br>Strategic Asset Allocation. The CIO has a asset allocation group that is<br>responsible for making tactical asset allocation decisions, including the<br>decision on the split between Swedish and global equities. (with the help of<br>the Portfolio Analysis group)</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The overall equity team structure is designed to play to the Fund’s perceived<br>strengths which are in Swedish equity and in carrying out sector analysis in 3<br>global sectors (IT, Healthcare and consumer). The Equity Committee will<br>make sector decisions, but the aim of the process is to deliver risk budgets to<br>the equity team (which includes the 3 global sector teams).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s approach to risk and retum is to understand and identify where and<br>how the “bets” should be taken to realistically achieve a certain retum target.<br>This will drive the tracking error/active risk budget for that asset class.</p>
<p>• For example, the Fund believes that it has a competitive advantage in Swedish<br>equity and therefore this has resulted... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The expected return target... (sekretessbelagt). The Fund is still in the process<br>of developing its approach to global equity management. One option is to use<br>passive sector funds as “fillers” in areas that the Fund does not feel that it can<br>add value.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For bonds they have decided not to adopt a market cap based approach but<br>rather to tilt the global bond portfolio toward those countries that are more<br>prudent, and therefore have a lower debt.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund feels that the average experience level of management of Swedish<br>Equity is high and this is complemented by the new but experienced Fixed<br>Income professionals that have been recently recruited. The CEO also made<br>the point that it will not be easy to recruit high quality equity professionals to<br>help in the management of the global equity exposure.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The overall compliance assessment process is detailed and covers investment<br>risk (and compliance) as well as operational risk.</p>
<p>The return targets and risk mandates by asset class, determined by the Board<br>are sensible.</p>
<p>2.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Operation</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund uses State Street as the custodian for non-Swedish assets and Nordea<br>for Swedish assets.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has invested in a new IT system. The AP Fund uses TMS 2000 as<br>the front and back office system, which appears to have good functionalities.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The overall cost budget, defined as fraction of asset under management, is 14<br>base points.</p>
<p>2.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;People</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In order to evaluate the organisation’s strength and consistency we need to<br>define the officers’ job descriptions with emphasis on responsibilities,<br>adequacy of resources and incentives.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Board main responsibilities:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;compliance with legislation and restrictions</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;“Goal and Instruction” document</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ongoing Investment direction</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CEO responsibilities</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;secure that the ongoing management and activities are in compliance<br>with the law, instructions and action plans</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;implement board decisions</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;report to the board</p>
<p>responsibility limits, new product and markets and larger investments</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;responsibility for business and&nbsp;risk control</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;responsibility for employees</p>
<p>The MD/CEO will also take part in the Finance Committee</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The CEO has been with the fund for 15 years and has 25 years of industry<br>experience.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Deputy CEO will have responsibility for the unquoted Equity portfolio.<br>The Deputy CEO is a part of the Investment Committee.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Chief Investment Officer has responsibility for operative responsibility for<br>the Fund’s management of assets.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Director of Administration has responsibility for the business<br>administration.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Business and Risk Control Unit has responsibility for establishing risk and<br>control document and monitoring compliance with this.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund tries to pay fixed salaries according to local practice compared with<br>the peer group.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has a temporary incentive program that will be revised next year.<br>The maximum bonus is 3 months salary.</p>
<p>2.5 Mercer view</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The in-house team has a long tradition in equity management and is large<br>compared with other funds, including 8 sector analysts/portfolio managers and<br>3 portfolio analysts. The philosophy toward equity management has been<br>carried over and could be described as a thematic/sector approach with<br>structured tilts away from the benchmark. Brokerage research is leveraged by<br>careful selection with a regular scoring system.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund appears to have a good understanding of its strengths, and indeed has<br>devised an approach that plays to this. We would encourage the Fund not to<br>ignore investment opportunities in which they have an acknowledged<br>weakness, but to consider ways of accessing these, perhaps via extemal<br>management capability (our concem being that the Fund needs to ensure that<br>the investment process is not unduly biased towards its perceived strengths<br>instead of the available opportunity set).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The approach to risk management is quite comprehensive and clearly there is a<br>good understanding of the issues involved. Risk Controls are monitored<br>independently of the investment team with weekly reports going directly to the<br>CEO. Compliance at different levels and operational risk is also very</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>comprehensive and is to be commended. The Fund has used an experienced<br>extemal consultant to support the work with risk control.</p>
<p>The fixed income team on the other hand is new and is organised along<br>different risk profiles, which is a sensible approach to specialisation.</p>
<p>The new Board of 9 was appointed in May 2000 (there being some continuity<br>from the previous Boards). Its work over the course of 6/7 meetings last year<br>would appear to be quite comprehensive with a number of documents having<br>been drafted to cover corporate governance, goals and guidelines, risk<br>management etc. Work continues to put in place policy and procedures in a<br>number of other areas. This is a team that has a long tradition in equity<br>management and it believes that it has the resources and experience to fulfil its<br>mandate. The approach to risk management is comprehensive and well<br>understood. The organisation is well structured and the only concern is the<br>cost, which is slightly on the high side. The Fund is one of the largest funds<br>after the re-organisation with a planed headcount of 45. This organisation is<br>quite comprehensive, perhaps at a certain cost with an overall budget<br>representing about 14 basis points of assets under management (the ambition<br>is to have a operating expense of about 10 basis points of the total assets).</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 ALM</p>
<p>3.1 Objective Setting</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The study commissioned by the Fund considered in some detail the role of the<br>buffer funds within the overall system.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The objective setting discussion concluded that the volatility of the investment<br>strategy is likely to have a limited impact on the Balanstal (on the grounds that<br>the overall pensions debt is ten times the size of the buffer funds).<br>Furthermore, the Balanstal was subject to variability in demographic factors<br>which it was not possible to “control” through choice of investment strategy.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The study resolved that the decision on asset allocation should focus on<br>generating minimum real returns and on the Fondstyrka (ie the ratio of the<br>Buffer Fund to total Pensions Debt). The retum measure was therefore the<br>Excess Retum over the Income Index (the Fondstyrka being another way of<br>measuring this) and the risk measure used was the probability of the Excess<br>Retum falling below 0% pa. The analysis considered periods of 10 years and<br>abo ve.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A period of 10 years was used for selecting the optimal policy.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The study did not consider competitive issues (relative to the other AP Funds)<br>in the objective setting process.</p>
<p>Methodology/Assumptions</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The approach was to optimise risk/retum using a standard mean-variance<br>optimisation process.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Liabilities were not modelled explicitly.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A “least-risk” portfolio... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The retum assumptions were based on a mix of existing information from<br>Capital markets, historical data and a judgmental overlay.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Swedish Equity return... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nominal bonds were treated as a single asset class (ie no distinction was made<br>between Swedish and non-Swedish bonds). The global bond portfolio was<br>constructed by having a strategic bias to countries with a good record on debt.</p>
<p>Analysis of Results</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A number of portfolios with real rates of return between 2.8% pa and 4% were<br>identified.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The proposed portfolio was one that provided the best trade-off between risk<br>and return (using a time horizon of 10 years).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The risk of the portfolio was reviewed over different time-horizons.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The proposed portfolio... (sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(sekretessbelagt).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund believes that it has a competitive advantage in Swedish equities and<br>therefore believes it can add more alpha in Swedish equities than in global<br>equities.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There was a belief that index-linked bonds have good Iiability-matching<br>characteristics.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The result of the above was an asset allocation which had a reduced strategic<br>allocation to equity to address the issues above. The exposure to Swedish<br>equity was also increased (more then doubled) from that emanating from the<br>ALM study.</p>
<p>Mercer View</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It is seldom possible to say definitively that an investment strategy decision is<br>incorrect as it is a judgement entirely dependent upon risk tolerance and the<br>need to accept risk. Very high equity weightings could be justified in the<br>context of the AP Funds, as could very low weightings. No real guidance is<br>given to the AP Funds in quantitative terms on the acceptable level of risk in<br>the context of the broader State pension system. The need to compete with<br>other AP Funds may in the long run drive funds towards high equity<br>weightings, although such considerations were not explicitly factored in to the<br>Fund’s analysis.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The most prominent deficiency in the ALM process, and one that all the Funds<br>faced, was effectively modelling a link between assets and liabilities beyond<br>purely inflation. It is this area in which we believe risk is most likely to be<br>understated. A link between recession, reduced contribution income and poor<br>equity returns is highly plausible and it is precisely this sort of scenario that<br>will adversely affect an equity-biased AP Fund to a potentially substantial<br>degree. More work needs to be undertaken in this area.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although we understand the rationale for overweighting Swedish Equity, we<br>would have more comfort with a justification based solely on strategic grounds<br>rather then on the grounds that the Fund has a perceived expertise in this area.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On the whole the investment policy decision making process is sound and the<br>Fund has identified a number of areas in which it needs to carry out more<br>work.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4 Overall Assessment</p>
<p>4.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section is intended to be an overall assessment based on our discussions with all<br>the Funds. Some of the points are more relevant to some Funds and less to others.</p>
<p>4.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have been impressed by the overall quality, experience and motivation of the<br>professionals that we met. Hard work has accomplished a great deal in a relatively<br>short time span, either to create a totally new organisation or to undertake a major re-<br>structuring of existing funds.</p>
<p>4.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In spite of new Board of Directors that include a varying proportion of non-initiated<br>people, they have also clearly risen to the challenge and have worked diligently with<br>management to set the framework for operating the system. To ensure their continuing<br>support, and although we understand the spirit of public service in Sweden, we wonder<br>if their remuneration could not be raised from the current SKr. 50,000 p.a.</p>
<p>4.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;We have the same kind of concerns regarding the compensation of the fund<br>professionals. While we can understand the attraction of the challenge of these new<br>funds for investment professionals, with the focus on hands on investment<br>management and an absence of bureaucracy compared with the mega-fmancial<br>institutions of today, at one point money does talk. Our concern is mostly on the bonus<br>side where the 6 months salary cap is clearly not in line with industry practice.<br>Personnel retention may become a real issue, especially as other third party managers<br>will come to view these people as providing an entry point into these fonds. Although<br>we must emphasise that we have in no way detected this, it might be natural for<br>investment professionals to view a couple of years at an AP Fund in the same light and<br>good on a resumé. This is some thing we have observed with the investment teams of<br>Central Banks or Generational Funds. If this were to occur, it would clearly be<br>detrimental to the long term performance of the Funds.</p>
<p>4.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another aspect to this, is that it seem to us that the intent of the legislator in setting up<br>these competing funds was to generate a heaithy competition to boost the overall risk<br>adjusted retum of the buffer fond system. This would be better accomplished by a<br>clear linkage between value creation and remuneration, including short and longer<br>term incentives. The opposite risk in the absence of this linkage is that all the fonds<br>will basically revert over time to a peer group average.</p>
<p>4.6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have found all the fonds to place risk control at the forefront of their concerns<br>which is clearly within their mandate. By and large this is monitored in an appropriate<br>fashion in terms of its independence from investment management, reporting lines to<br>the CEO/Board and the type of reports. The only fundamental observation for possible<br>review, is that risk management cannot be condensed into one statistic, notably<br>tracking error, but must be reviewed in multiple cuts to understand the type of risk the<br>overall fond is taking and whether these are consistent with the house view or among<br>the various internal/external mandates. We suspect that for the most part this is being</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>done, (for example some of the Funds are using BARRA type analysis) but our<br>cursory review of necessity could not reveal this in detail. We would also suggest that<br>risk management become fully integrated as part of the investment management<br>process (some of the funds do this already).</p>
<p>4.7 &nbsp;&nbsp;The Funds tend to use domestic custodians (some use domestic and non-domestic<br>custodians). Although we did not have an opportunity to review this in detail, our<br>sense is that the risk and compliance services provided by custodians (the global<br>players) may be under utilised.</p>
<p>4.8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another observation for at least careful debate is whether the overall implementation<br>of tactical asset allocation overlay programs, with the notable exception of one of the<br>Funds, is necessarily appropriate given that this is an activity that requires skills that<br>are difficult to find and in which it is difficult to, consistently, add value.</p>
<p>4.9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;What is also interesting to us is that while the Funds have easily turned to external<br>managers to complement their internal expertise, this has not been the case for tactical<br>asset allocation, at least to gain an insight into some highly specialist managers are<br>doing in this area. This would seem to be the approach of some of the long standing,<br>sophisticated, in-house pension fund teams around the world, who do intemal<br>modelling but benchmark their approaches with outside TAA managers as well</p>
<p>4.10 &nbsp;A similar comment as in the previous paragraph, could cover the intent expressed in<br>most instances to make more active currency bets, especially as the currency exposure<br>regulations become more liberal over time. This is also an area of quite specific<br>expertise.</p>
<p>4.11 &nbsp;&nbsp;In fact a general observation is that the Funds might be trying to do too much,<br>especially in such a short period. It is sometimes better practice to implement a few<br>steps at a time, checking the procedures and finding the flaws in periods of difficult<br>market conditions. A related point is that a number of the Funds have devised<br>structures/process on the basis of their perceived investment management strengths.<br>This is only natural, we would however urge the Funds to consider carefully the full<br>investment opportunity set and the best way of accessing this.</p>
<p>4.12 &nbsp;Those Funds which have carried out the strategy setting exercise have done so, in<br>general, thoroughly. The areas that we feel are worthy of further analysis are strategies<br>that provide for less correlated exposure to the fortunes of the Sweden economy. A<br>number of the strategies have a bias to Swedish equities on the ground of a link<br>between wage growth and the Swedish equity market, it would be interesting to<br>explore whether there is any evidence for this.</p>
<p>4.13 &nbsp;We would concur with an observation which was often made to us, that the Public<br>Authority status of the funds, on balance was not helpful. This touches on the<br>compensation issues mentioned above, but also the everyday regulatory burden that<br>this imposes. A particular aspect of this is the somewhat uncertain mandate of AP6<br>which in limiting its private equity investments to Sweden, might imply a social<br>responsibility to assist Swedish start-ups whatever their merits. This is being resisted,<br>as illustrated by the number of deals offered to the fund and the high number that are<br>being turned down, but there is the perception of political sensitivities that at one point<br>might be detrimental to the performance of the fund.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>10</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4.14 It might be a good idea to introduce some economic measures of how the AP Fund<br>organisations are accomplishing their mandate. This implies the active monitoring of<br>intemal versus extemal asset management, but also the “bottom line” of the funds<br>themselves. In our experience there is no clear cut model of in-house versus total<br>outsourcing, and various combinations, as in Sweden, are generally accepted, at least<br>in the public area, like the State pension funds in the US or the generational funds<br>(ADIA, MAS, Norway Oil Fund). There has been a trend away from in-house in the<br>private sector but mostly because of focus of resources or the desire to unlock value.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>11</p>
<p>AP Fund 4<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Appendix A</p>
<p>Risk Warnings</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;Past performance cannot be relied upon as a guide to future performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;The value of stocks and shares, including unitised funds, can go down as well as up and<br>you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;The value of bonds and other fixed income investments including unitised funds can go<br>down as well as up and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;Investments denominated in a foreign currency will fluctuate with the value of the<br>currency.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;The value of investments in real property can go down as well as up, and you may not get<br>back the amount you have invested. Valuation is generally a matter of a valuer’s opinion,<br>rather than fact. It may be difficult or impossible to realise an investment because the<br>property concemed may not be readily saleable.</p>
