<p>A &nbsp;Risk Warnings</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;i&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Investment Consulting &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Introduction</p>
<p>l. 1 Objective of evaluation</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance has assigned William M. Mercer Ltd to evaluate each AP<br>Fund. The objective of the assignment is to evaluate each Fund’s organisational<br>structure, and to appraise this structure in light of its mandate. Particular focus will be<br>placed on the risk Controls and the Fund’s ongoing compliance with the objectives set<br>by its board.</p>
<p>Our review was based on reviewing working papers and documents provided by the<br>Fund, telephone conversations and one meeting with key members of AP6. We would<br>like to stress that our mandate was limited to carrying out a high level review of the<br>Funds, and not a detailed due diligence of the organisation.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of the AP Funds’ respective mandates</p>
<p>The First to Fourth and Sixth AP Funds have mandates to manage the buffer funds in<br>the new reformed pension system. The Sixth AP Fund represents the new name for<br>what was formerly known as the Sixth Fund Board. The Sixth Fund board has not<br>been reorganised over year 2000, only the name has been changed. As from the start<br>of 2001, new investment rules entered into force for the Sixth AP Fund but the<br>mandate for the Sixth AP Fund will be the same.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of key responsibilities of the Board</p>
<p>The number of Board members for each fund is set to 5 members. The main<br>responsibilities are to establish the Investment Policy, Ownership Policy/Corporate<br>Govemance and Risk Control Plan. We note that for the First to Fourth AP Funds this<br>is explicitly set out in the legislation. We understand that this is not the case for the<br>Sixth AP Fund, however the Board of the Sixth Fund carries out essentially a similar<br>function. The Board can delegate responsibilities to the MD/CEO according to the<br>Law.</p>
<p>Divyesh Hindocha</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Johan Sidenmark</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Review of Organisation</p>
<p>2.1 Overall organisation</p>
<p>The Fund has created a structured organisation with well-defined roles and<br>responsibilities for all activities. The complete organisation of approximately 47<br>employees as at 2001 is illustrated in the organisation chart below:</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-420.png" style="width:292pt;height:278pt;"/>
<p>Based on our meeting with the Fund it is not absolutely clear to us what the mission of<br>the Fund is. Our original understanding was that the singular purpose of the Fund was<br>to create value through investment in private equity. We have subsequently been<br>informed that the Fund sees its mission as more wide ranging, specifically their<br>mission includes “providing equity and competence to small and medium sized<br>companies”.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Given their mission and the realities of private equity opportunities (which are<br>currently limited to Sweden), it is perhaps not surprising that the portfolio includes<br>quoted companies as well, which are set apart from the private equity management.<br>The size of the exposure to the quoted portfolio, although declining (over the year<br>2000 the overall exposure to the quoted portfolio reduced from close to 90% down to<br>about 80%) is higher then would be case if the private equity opportunity set were<br>bigger.</p>
<p>The Board is divided into a series of sub-committees, which oversee every important<br>aspect of the operations of the Fund:</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Committee-overall</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Finance Committee-responsible for listed portfolio</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment Committee-Private equity investments of over SKr 20 million</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Intemal Board-each investment unit</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IT Committee</p>
<p>&quot; The Fund has defined its financial objective to generate a retum that exceeds an<br>appropriate equity index for the quoted portfolio and a retum of 16%pa for the<br>unquoted portfolio.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The retum of 16% for the unquoted portfolio was constructed as follows:</p>
<p>Long term expected return on bonds: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5%</p>
<p>Quoted equity risk premium: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4%</p>
<p>Unquoted equity risk premium: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4%</p>
<p>Costs: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3%</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each of the Quoted and the Unquoted units are run autonomously with<br>appropriate support from the Business Unit.</p>
<p>2.2 Management of the Assets</p>
<p>Quoted Investments/Asset Management</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The asset management unit carries out its role by investing in a variety of<br>different strategies:</p>
<p>- The majority of the assets (close to 80%) are invested in a Benchmark<br>Portfolio. This can be considered as a standard Swedish mandate with the<br>team taking sector/stock positions with the objective of outperforming the<br>index.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A material proportion of the assets is invested in Strategic Holdings. These<br>are holdings where AP6 have Board level involvement with a view to<br>contributing to the development of these companies.</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There are small investments in the area of Financial Engineering (the aim<br>of this sub-unit is to profit from arbitrage opportunities linked to M&amp;A<br>activity) and investments with Extemal Managers (comprising of<br>investments in two mutual funds and one hedge fund).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There is also a unit that manages short term assets. This has a maximum of<br>Skr 100m allocated to it and an absolute profit target of Skr 10m.</p>
<p>The activities of Asset Management are subject to oversight by the Financial<br>Committee. The Committee puts in place overall limits on sector weights and<br>also sets a performance target for each of the sub-units. The target tracking error<br>for the Benchmark portfolio is 4%pa with a total target tracking error for the<br>Quoted Investments 6%pa. The total target added value for Quoted Investments<br>is 0.5%pa.</p>
<p>Over the year 2000 the total performance of the Asset Management Unit was a<br>creditable -6.3% compared to the chosen benchmark retum of-11.9%.<br>Underperformance in the Benchmark Portfolio, Extemal Management, and<br>losses in Financial Engineering were offset by the added value from the<br>Strategic Holdings which had a very strong year.</p>
<p>Unquoted Investments/Private Equity</p>
<p>The Unquoted Investments/Private Equity unit invests in the following<br>strategies:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Buy-outs (about 36% of the total invested and committed investments).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Industrial ventures (about 11% of the total invested and committed<br>investments).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Technology ventures (about 29% of the total invested and committed<br>investments).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Life Science ventures (about 24% of the total invested and committed<br>investments).</p>
<p>Each of the teams (buy-out, life Science ventures etc) carries out due diligence<br>on ideas and makes “buy” recommendations to the Investment Committee for<br>approval. The Investment Committee can only sanction deals of up to Skr 20m.<br>Other deals and all the buy-out deal proposals have to be approved by the Board.</p>
<p>The Fund strongly believes that there are synergies between the Quoted<br>Investments and Unquoted Investments. For example the activities of the quoted<br>companies (eg a cancellation of a major order or a change in strategy) can help<br>in the evaluation of a buy-out opportunity.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The investment strategy for private equity has evolved over the years, from a<br>highly cautious attitude of taking small minority stakes of between 10-15%,<br>resulting in a highly diversified portfolio (70 direct holdings), to larger stakes of<br>30-40%. The philosophy remains of keeping to minority stakes and co-investing<br>with other well-established institutions. The average investment remains on the<br>small side at approximately Skr 50 million. Realised gains to date have been<br>largely through trade sales (to other companies). Private equity investments are<br>leveraged by investing in other manager’s funds, although these opportunities<br>are somewhat finite also.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;They have already started to prepare for investments outside Sweden by building<br>contacts and a network.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Group Controller monitors compliance with guidelines directly to the CEO<br>and Chief Operating Officer and if necessary directly to Board of Directors.<br>Group Control is separate from the investment operations. The Fund has a Risk<br>Manager - Asset Management who reports to the Group Controller. The Group<br>Controller is responsible for the overall risk exposure and is also the Risk<br>Manager for the Unquoted Investments.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The valuation policy for private equity is only based on industry guidelines<br>(based on the European Venture Capital Association rules).</p>
<p>2.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Operational Issues</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund uses Handelsbanken as the custodian bank.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund uses TMS 2000 as front office system, which appears to have good<br>functionalities.</p>
<p>2.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;People</p>
<p>The responsibilities of the various parties can be summarised as follows:</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Board</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;compliance with law and restrictions</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decide the Investment Policy</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decide on Investment overall investment direction</p>
<p>• CEO</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;secure that the ongoing management and activities are in compliance with<br>the law, instructions and polices</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;implement board decisions</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;report to the board</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;draw-up proposals and changes for the Investment Policy</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;draw-up Business/Activity Plan including investment goals etc</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;operational responsibility for all other organisational issues</p>
<p>operational responsibility all decisions within the Investment Policy</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;compliance with Investment Policy</p>
<p>extemal communication</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;responsibility for employees</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the CEO will also take part in the Investment Committee.</p>
<p>- CFO</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Chief Financial Officer has responsibility for ongoing control and<br>motoring including laws and restrictions on an overriding level.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Group Controller</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Group Controller has responsibility to ensure that the intemal policy<br>and limits are followed and to report to the CEO and CFO or if necessary<br>to the Board of Directors, including any violation of investment<br>limitations.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund recognises that the compensation package is competitive for<br>“Gothenburg Standards” but not compared with a similar peer groups in<br>Stockholm or internationally. The perceived advantages for the employee are<br>working for a stable employer, a lifestyle change, and the kudos of working with<br>a large player in the market.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An incentive program was put in place in 2000 with a clear connection between<br>the individuals contribution and the bonus. The bonus system reflects the Public<br>Authority status of the Fund with the result that the maximum bonus is 50% of<br>the annual salary.</p>
<p>2.5 Mercer View</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although the “Gothenburg effect” can come into play in terms of life style<br>issues, one would have to question longer term, whether staff retention will not<br>be affected by a relatively ungenerous incentive scheme by private equity<br>standards. An alternative scheme to invest the proceeds of the cash bonus, such<br>as it is, back into the Fund was discarded as being too complicated and a<br>potential conflict of interest, which we would concur with.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The added value expectation from the Quoted Investment of 0.5%pa (and hence<br>an information ratio 0.08) appears conservative given the target tracking error of<br>6%pa and the number of different strategies that are employed.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund is of the view that the activities of the Private Equity unit provides<br>material support to the Quoted Investments team. In their view this results in<br>sufficient resources being devoted to Quoted Investments. In our view the<br>resources devoted to the Quoted Investments (a maximum of 6 at full capacity)<br>seem to be at odds with the actual exposure to Quoted Investments of close to<br>80% of the assets. In other words, we have some concerns in respect of the<br>resources being devoted to the management of close to 80% of the Fund<br>investments.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We found that the level of understanding of issues related to investing in private<br>equity was very good and the investment procedures and subsequent monitoring<br>of investments as they were described to us as sound. It was encouraging to hear<br>that they have started to think and prepare for their expected change in mandate,<br>which will allow them to invest outside Sweden. It will interesting to see how<br>they capitalise on their increased geographic discretion.</p>
<p>* Although the stated mission of the Fund includes investing in Quoted<br>Investments, a significant part of this portfolio is a reserve fund pending<br>investments in private equity. There is some question as to the extent to which<br>this pool of assets will be invested in the finite opportunities for private equity in<br>Sweden, at least if quality standards are to be maintained. Giving the Fund the<br>discretion to invest outside Sweden will open up the opportunity set (bringing<br>with it the added benefit of diversification) and also allow the Fund to determine<br>its long term strategy in respect of the balance between quoted and unquoted<br>investments. In our view it would be useful to clarify the mission of the Fund,<br>specifically the extent to which it should be invested in listed companies (other<br>than those which it has nurtured and brought to the market).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are not sure we understand the logic of the various alternative strategies<br>employed in the Quoted Investments. The Strategic Holdings which include in<br>some instances Board of Director representation to assist these companies in<br>realising value, would appear a dilution of the funds primary objective. We feel<br>that it is appropriate for the Fund to continue to unravel these holdings, even<br>though they contributed the most positively to returns in 2000 for instance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We understand that the arbitrage activities have been suspended after the<br>departure of this team, which is fortuitous as again we see this type of activity as<br>straying too far from the primary mandate of the Fund. Similarly, we would<br>view the trading portfolio as management of near cash for funds to be called on<br>in private equity, but we would recommend that this not include any speculative<br>element. We understand the value of a knowledgeable trader in adding value in<br>managing the portfolio but would question the “trading account” approach akin<br>to proprietary trading carried out by investment banks.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are not wholly convinced of the synergies between the quoted and unquoted<br>portfolios. Given the specialised nature of the asset class, most private equity<br>managers are dedicated to the management of this asset class</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The use of Extemal Managers in not meaningful in term of actual absolute<br>amount of investment made. Although the amounts are small this investments<br>have the potential to distract management especially as one of the investments is<br>in a hedge fund which we envisage needs careful monitoring. In our view the<br>role of Asset Management should be clarified with perhaps the focus being re-<br>directed to the Benchmark Portfolio.</p>
<p>Risk control, while labour intensive, allows for a good understanding of the<br>particular risks associated with each investment unit and represents a good<br>approach to risk control. The activities of the Financial Committee in<br>overseeing, at weekly meetings, the listed portfolio and the combination of the<br>Investment Committee and the full Board for the private equity portfolio, would<br>appear appropriate.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 Overall Assessment</p>
<p>Assessment</p>
<p>We found the approach to private equity sensible and competent and the necessary<br>checks and balances in place. There is some ambiguity possibly in the Fund’s<br>mandate, limited as it is to Swedish private equity, and the staff is conscious of some<br>political sensitivities that may arise in the course of making investments and managing<br>these investments.</p>
<p>As we discussed we do question some aspects of the way the listed portfolio has been<br>managed with regard to the strategic holdings, arbitrage and the trading portfolio. At<br>the very least these aspects are a distraction from what should be the main focus of the<br>Fund. Given the Fund’s stated mission, we can understand investments being made in<br>small/medium sized companies (to whom the Fund may be able to bring expertise) but<br>we are not convinced of the rationale for investing in the broad market (other then the<br>lack of alternative opportunities). If the conclusion was that the Fund will (needs to)<br>continue to invest in the broad market because of fundamentally finite opportunities,<br>consideration should be given allocating this part of this portfolio to a manager<br>(another AP fund?) whose structure was explicitly designed to manage mainstream<br>equity investment.</p>
<p>We commend the staff on maintaining quality Controls on investments in private<br>equity and fulfilling correctly its mandate and in the interest of diversification, we<br>would consider allowing a certain level of investment outside Sweden, probably<br>through established funds managed by quality managers. We believe this would help<br>in developing further the Swedish market as well by encouraging more International<br>sourcing and co-investment.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 6</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Appendix A</p>
<p>Risk Warnings</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Past performance Cannot be relied upon as a guide to future performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of stocks and shares, including unitised funds, can go down as well as up and<br>you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of bonds and other fixed income investments including unitised funds can go<br>down as well as up and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments denominated in a foreign currency will fluctuate with the value of the<br>currency.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of investments in real property can go down as well as up, and you may not<br>get back the amount you have invested. Valuation is generally a matter of a valuer’s<br>opinion, rather than fact. It may be difficult or impossible to realise an investment<br>because the property concerned may not be readily saleable.</p>

<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Executive Summary</p>
<p>1.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Strategy</p>
<p>The underlying objective of the Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund Private Equity<br>portfolio is to maximise returns on a long-term basis having due regard to the need for<br>risk diversification. The return objective has been translated into a broad overall<br>“hurdle-rate” guideline of 16% annual IRR.</p>
<p>The total portfolio grew to SEK 4,159.0m as at 31 December 2000 from SEK<br>2,536.6m at 31 December 1999, and is expected to grow to SEK 5,512m by 31<br>December 2001. Private equity investment staffing levels increased from 20.5 to 28<br>by 31 December 2000. These staffing levels are expected to increase to 33 by 31<br>December 2001.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Performance</p>
<p>Total portfolio annual IRR, as at 31 December 2000, was 21.6% p.a. compared with<br>21.06% p.a. at 31 December 1999 and -3.5% at the end of 1998 thus indicating a<br>traditional “J-curve” effect. However, we would urge caution against looking at IRR<br>figures after only 3-4 years as a basis of performance measurement due to the<br>conservative methodology used (as recommended by the EVCA). Within this total<br>IRR figure of 21.6% p.a., Fund investments retumed an IRR of 62.2% p.a.; Unrealised<br>Direct investments retumed an annual IRR of 2.5% p.a. and Realised Direct<br>Investments retumed an IRR of -13.2% p.a.</p>
<p>The most significant positive individual performances were the Innovationskapital I<br>(IRR at 215.4%) and Tribon Solutions (IRR at 182.0%). The most significant<br>individual negative performances came from NetSYS (SEK 297.5m written-off) and<br>Biora (SEK 164.8m valued down). Note that Biora is a quoted investment.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Portfolio Value</p>
<p>The total portfolio was valued at SEK 4,159.0m at 31 December 2000 of which Fund<br>investments were SEK 1,810.3m (43.5%) and Unrealised Direct investments were<br>SEK 2,348.7m (56.5%).</p>
<p>1.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Portfolio Diversification</p>
<p>There continues to be an adequate sectoral spread and exposure to investments in the<br>expansion and start-up stages has fallen (41.4% at 31 December 2000, compared to<br>67.9% the previous year), due to a re-classification of stages, the total private equity<br>portfolio now has a 48.2% exposure to the growth/mature stage. In addition, there is<br>now no exposure to Seed companies. Unrestricted quoted equities accounted for 6.1%<br>of the total private equity portfolio.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund<br>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>As previously noted, there is a lack of geographic diversification (due to legal<br>constraints).</p>
<p>1.5 Other Points</p>
<p>We note that the Fund has adopted an annual IRR target of 16%pa.</p>
<p>We have a number of other comments related to the chosen investment strategy of the<br>Fund. These comments are set out on the document titled “Review of Organisation”.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Private Equity Portfolio Objectives and<br>Strategy</p>
<p>2.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Requirement of the Act (as it relätes to Private Equity)</p>
<p>2.1.1 &nbsp;Organisation</p>
<p>There shall be 5 Board members decided by the Government</p>
<p>2.1.2 &nbsp;Return</p>
<p>• &nbsp;Make equity investments to achieve maximum benefit for the pension<br>system</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Goal is high return, long-term investments and risk diversification</p>
<p>2.1.3 &nbsp;Allowable Asset Classes</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Equities in Swedish Companies</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Convertibles of Swedish Companies</p>
<p>• &nbsp;Swedish Private Equity</p>
<p>• &nbsp;Risk Capital exposure</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund may own up to 30% of the voting<br>power in a registered company (excludes private equity)</p>
<p>2.1.4 &nbsp;Other</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Fund Board may appoint external managers for specialist briefs in special<br>areas.</p>
<p>2.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund Objectives and Strategy</p>
<p>In implementing the requirements of the Act the Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund<br>Board broadly defines its strategic responsibilities as follows:</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;To manage the national pensions so that the requirement of return is fulfilled</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;To offer risk Capital to the Swedish market with a view to achieving high returns</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;To focus on small and mid capitalisation companies</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund<br>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>In so doing the Board has set an intemal “hurdle rate” target of 16% IRR as its<br>investment objective. They estimate that this return should deliver, in the long-term,<br>an excess return of +4% over the expected quoted Swedish equity market return.</p>
<p>We note that there do not appear to be any specific guidelines or objectives set by the<br>Ministry of Finance in terms of the expected long-term contribution by the Sixth<br>Swedish National Pension Fund to the State Pension System. The result is that total<br>assets under management will continue to grow, having more than quadrupled since<br>the Fund’s inception to circa SEK 4.2B. The private equity component is expected to<br>reach SEK 5.5B by the end of 2001.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 Total Portfolio</p>
<p>When evaluating private equity performance at a portfolio level, investors should be<br>wary when looking at short-term IRR results or at results which display large<br>fluctuations arising from a few highly advantageous disinvestments. The long-term<br>perspective is key, but as a guide historic experience would suggest that it is only after<br>four to five years that IRR results start to indicate a discernible trend.</p>
<p>All performance numbers in this section are based on annual IRR calculations in<br>accordance with EVCA guidelines, with all data being supplied by the Sixth Swedish<br>National Pension Fund.</p>
<p>FOR AVOIDANCE OF DOUBT REFERENCE TO THE TOTAL PORTFOLIO<br>IN THIS REPORT IS TO THE TOTAL PRIVATE EQUITY PORTFOLIO</p>
<p>3.1 Performance to 31 December 2000</p>
<p>In the table below we show the performance of the Sixth Swedish National Pension<br>Fund Total Private Equity portfolio from inception to 31 December 2000, as well as<br>the evolution of the IRR on an annual basis.</p>

<p>■ &nbsp;To 31 December 2000 the Total Portfolio has an IRR of 21.6% p.a.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;The majority of this performance can be attributed to performance of the “Funds”<br>component of the Total Portfolio, with the “Realised” component being the largest<br>detractor from performance. The poor performance within the “Realised”<br>portfolio was driven by the large number of investments that were written-off.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;The evolution of the IRR’s continues to show the traditional private equity “J-<br>curve” characteristic, with investments showing a negative retum in their early life<br>and growth in following years.</p>
<p>3.2 Asset Distribution at 31 December 2000</p>
<p>The value of the Total Portfolio as measured by the EVCA guidelines, was SEK<br>4,159.0m as at 31 December 2000. This was split 56.5% to direct investments and<br>43.5% to indirect (“Funds”) investment.</p>

<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>

<p>□ Funds □ Swedestart II Q Innovationskapital I</p>
<p>* To 31 December 2000 the Fund Portfolio has an IRR of 62.2% pa.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Approximately 22.2% of the performance of the Funds Portfolio can be attributed<br>to two Funds. Innovationskapital I (which accounts for 8.7%&gt; of the portfolio)<br>contributed 13.9% of the performance and Swedestart II (which accounts for 3.3%<br>of the portfolio) contributed 8.3% of the performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Within the Funds portfolio the Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund are invested<br>in a total of 24 funds, of which 10 were added during 2000. Of the 24 funds, 3 are<br>valued at book cost and 15 are valued above book cost, with the remaining 6 valued<br>below book cost.</p>
<p>4.2 Asset Distribution at 31 December 2000</p>

<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>5 Unrealised Direct Investments</p>
<p>5.1 Performance to 31 December 2000</p>
<p>In the chart below we show the performance of the Sixth Swedish National Pension<br>Fund Unrealised Direct Investments private equity portfolio from inception to 31<br>December 2000, as well as the evolution of the IRR on an annual basis.</p>
<p>Annual IRR: Unrealised Direct Investments</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-436.png" style="width:340pt;height:173pt;"/>
<p>□ Unrealised</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;To 31 December 2000 the portfolio has an IRR of 2.5% pa. The IRR evolution<br>shows a characteristic “J-curve” effect but is rather flat considering the scale of the<br>performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;This performance can be positively attributed to Tribon Solutions, Karo Bio and<br>Nordisk Renting. Negative attribution can be spread over numerous investments,<br>the worst of which are Biora and Gotaverken Miljo AB.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Within the portfolio the Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund are invested in 66<br>stocks, of which 36 are valued at book cost, 12 are valued up and 18 are valued<br>down.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>15</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund<br>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>5.2 Asset Distribution at 31 December 2000</p>
<p>The value of the Unrealised Direct Investments portfolio, as measured in accordance<br>with EVCA guidelines, was SEK 2,348.7m as at 31 December 2000.</p>
<p>5.2.1 By Stage</p>
<p>The asset distribution for the portfolio at 31 December 2000, split by the<br>various private equity stages, is given in the pie chart below.</p>
<p>Stage Distribution: Unrealised Portfolio</p>
<p>5</p>
<p>61.4%</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-437.png" style="width:234pt;height:94pt;"/>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Stage Code</p></td><td>
<p>Stage Name</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>1</p></td><td>
<p>Seed</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>2</p></td><td>
<p>Start Up</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>3</p></td><td>
<p>Expansion</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>4</p></td><td>
<p>International Expansion</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>5</p></td><td>
<p>Growth/Mature</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>6</p></td><td>
<p>Quoted stocks</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>■ &nbsp;The portfolio is biased towards stocks in the growth/mature stage of their<br>development, with the Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund holding 25<br>stocks in this stage.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;Investments in the start-up and expansion stages are roughly equal, with<br>quoted investments making up a smaller percentage of the portfolio. There<br>is still no exposure of stocks in the seed or intemational expansion stages.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;10.7% of the portfolio is invested in quoted stocks, with exposure limited</p>
<p>to five stocks.</p>
<table border="1">

<p>■ &nbsp;At 31 December 2000, 55.6% of the portfolio is invested in two sectors:<br>Healthcare and Financials (namely NS Holding and Nordisk Renting).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;The five largest direct unrealised holdings have a total value of SEK</p>
<p>1,050.2m and account for 51.3% of the portfolio.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>

<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>6 Realised Direct Investments</p>
<p>6.1 Performance to 31 December 2000</p>
<p>In the chart below we show the performance of the Sixth Swedish National Pension<br>Fund Realised Direct Investments private equity portfolio from inception to 31<br>December 2000, as well as the evolution of the IRR on an annual basis.</p>
<p>Annual IRR: Realised Direct Investments</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-439.png" style="width:332pt;height:171pt;"/>
<p>□ Realised □NetSYS □ Cyber Com Consulting □Essex Holding</p>
<p>To 31 December 2000 the Total Portfolio has an IRR of-13.2% pa.</p>
<p>The overall negative IRR on the realised portfolio is due to the large number of<br>investments that were written off over 2000, of which NetSYS (which accounts for<br>over 37% of invest Capital in the realised portfolio) is the largest contributor to the<br>poor performance, having an impact of -45.4% on the annual IRR.</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance may note that large increase in the IRR at 31 December<br>1999 (54.5% in this year’s report compared to 33.5% in our report last year). This<br>is due to the addition of Dressmart into the realised portfolio (from the unrealised<br>portfolio) which had a high valuation at 31 December 1999 (SEK 214m), compared<br>to the actual realised value later in 2000 (SEK 0).</p>
<p>Two investments made significant positive contributions to performance; Essex<br>Holding AB (which contributed 84.3% to performance) and Cyber Com<br>Consulting. The latter is a quoted investment.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>18</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ Further details on performance of each realised holding are given under Section 6.3<br>Portfolio Summary.</p>
<p>6.2 Asset Distribution at 31 December 2000</p>
<p>The total proceeds from the realised investments amounted to SEK 707.6m, with<br>investments being realised from the start-up or expansion stages (with the exception of<br>one investment in the growth/mature stage) and over various different sectors, but<br>mainly in the IT sector.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>19</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund<br>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>

<p>Bilaga 6</p>

<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>22</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>8 Summary</p>
<p>8.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total Portfolio</p>
<p>As at 31 December 2000 the total private equity portfolio was valued at SEK<br>4,159.0m, of which 56.5% related to Direct investments and 43.5% to Funds<br>investments.</p>
<p>Performance in 2000, as measured by annual IRR, was 21.6%, which showed a<br>marginal improvement over the 1999 result. However we would urge caution against<br>looking at IRR figures after only three years as historic experience would suggest that<br>it is only after four to five years that a more discernible trend emerges.</p>
<p>In terms of sector distribution, 37.7% of the total portfolio was invested in Healthcare,<br>with other investments mainly in Industrials, Financials and IT. The portfolio had a<br>strong bias towards the Growth/Mature stage (48.2%) and also included 6.1% invested<br>in five quoted stocks.</p>
<p>8.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Funds Investments</p>
<p>The Funds component of the portfolio, comprising of 24 separate funds, was valued at<br>SEK 1,810.3m and had an annual IRR of 62.2% as at 31 December 2000. This result<br>was much improved when compared with the 1999 IRR of 27.6% p.a. but, as<br>mentioned above, caution should be exercised when assessing this IRR figure after<br>only 3 years. Performance was mainly due to two funds; Swedestart II and<br>Innovationskapital I.</p>
<p>From a sectoral point of view, 44.6% of the Fund portfolio was invested in Heathcare,<br>while Start-up’s, at 33.8%, was the largest stage investment. There was a 0.1%<br>exposure to funds focusing on Seed businesses as at 31 December 2000.</p>
<p>Gross proceeds for the total Funds portfolio accounted to SEK 711.5m or 55% of<br>invested Capital.</p>
<p>8.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealised Direct Investments</p>
<p>Total Unrealised Direct Investments (66 stocks) amounted to SEK 2,348.7m as at 31<br>December 2000 and produced an annual IRR of 2.5%. The IRR evolution shows the<br>characteristic “J-curve” effect, albeit rather flat.</p>
<p>Positive performances from Tribon Solutions, Karo Biro and Nordisk Renting were<br>weighted down by Biora and Gotaverken Miljo AB.</p>
<p>Sectoral analysis shows that 55.6% of this portfolio was invested in Healthcare<br>(32.3%) and Financials (23.3%).</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>23</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>When looking at the stage distribution 61.4% of the unrealised direct investments<br>were invested in the Growth/Mature stage, while the five quoted stocks account for<br>10.7% of this portfolio.</p>
<p>8.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;Realised Direct Investments</p>
<p>As at 31 December 2000 the total portfolio (of 22 holdings) had an IRR of-13.2% p.a.<br>The most significant positive performers were Cyber Com Consulting (IRR of<br>7117.0% p.a.) and Essex Holdings AB (IRR of 70.6% p.a.). Written-off investments<br>in NetSYS, LINQ Systems, Svenska AB and Dessmart all had negative impacts on<br>performance.</p>
<p>Total realised proceeds amounted to SEK 707.6m, of which SEK 473.5m was<br>received during 2000. Of the investments realised in 2000 (11 in total), eight of the<br>holdings were either written-off or were negative performers while only three were<br>realised at profit.</p>
<p>8.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;Conclusion</p>
<p>Results in 2000 show a marginal improvement over 1999, with overall investments<br>reflecting the expected “J-curve” effect, although, due to several excellent performing<br>holdings, the positive total portfolio IRR result has come a little earlier than is normal.</p>
<p>Investments are still weighted towards direct investments (56.5%) at the expense of<br>fund investments (43.5%). However over the last year we have already seen a +10%<br>swing in the portfolios, and we expect this to continue over the next few years.</p>
<p>Overall realised (and unrealised to a lesser extent) direct investment results are<br>somewhat disappointing reflecting perhaps the difficulties and challenges of direct<br>investing.</p>
<p>On the question of risk diversification, there appears to be an adequate sectoral spread<br>and the portfolio is slowing gaining stage diversification but there still remains very<br>little exposure to Seed companies. This may be a function of the lack of sufficient<br>opportunities in the Swedish market.</p>
<p>Geographical diversification was still missing from the portfolio over 2000, but we<br>understand that measures have been taken in early 2001 to rectify this. We shall<br>monitor this in our next annual report.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>24</p>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>

<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Appendix C</p>
<p>Glossary of Private Equity Terms</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>BVCA</p></td><td>
<p>British Venture Capital Association.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Carried Interest</p></td><td>
<p>Mechanism by which a venture capitalist shares in the profits achieved<br>in a venture Capital fund or investment. Typically, 20% of the net gains<br>achieved by a venture Capital fund.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Deal Flow</p></td><td>
<p>The flow of investment propositions received by a venture capitalist.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Development Capital</p></td><td>
<p>Capital Investment into companies which are generally profitable, but<br>which require further equity finance to expand.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Distribution</p></td><td>
<p>A retum of cash or shares to an investor from a venture capitai fund.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Draw Down</p></td><td>
<p>A cash call of part or all of an investor’s outstanding commitment to a<br>venture Capital fund.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>EVCA</p></td><td>
<p>European Venture Capital Association</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Exit Route</p></td><td>
<p>The method by which the venture capitalist will realise his original<br>investment - usually by a trade sale or floatation.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Follow-on Investment</p></td><td>
<p>A further round of financing provided for a company subsequent to the<br>initial investment.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Flotation</p></td><td>
<p>Listing of a company’s sharers on the full market or a similar foreign<br>exchange.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>‘Hands-on’ Investor</p></td><td>
<p>An investor who is actively involved in the strategic, or day to day,<br>management of investee companies.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>IPO</p></td><td>
<p>Initial Public Offering - the US equivalent of a floatation.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>IRR</p></td><td>
<p>Intemal Rate of Retum - the annual rate of retum to the investor.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Later Stage</p></td><td>
<p>Incorporates expansion and development Capital, buy-outs, buy-ins<br>and mezzanine finance.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Net Asset Value</p></td><td>
<p>The balance sheet value of the assets of funds.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Passive Investor</p></td><td>
<p>Investor who does not get closely involved with investee companies.<br>Normally invests as a member of syndicated deal.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Private Equity</p></td><td>
<p>Provision of equity Capital for generally young, unquoted companies</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Investment Consulting</p></td><td>
<p>Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund<br>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td></td><td>
<p>with high growth potential - ranges from early through to late stage<br>investment. A key feature is the ‘hands-on’ involvement by the<br>investor to help in the growth and development of the company.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Secondary Purchase</p></td><td>
<p>Purchase of a holding of an existing venture Capital fund from an<br>investor who needs to sell. These can often be bought at a significant<br>discount.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Seed Capital</p></td><td>
<p>Investment at the earliest stage, often to help prove a concept or<br>develop an initial working prototype.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Syndicated</p>
<p>Investment</p></td><td>
<p>An investment which as been spread amongst several institutional<br>backers, generally because it is too large for a single investor to<br>provide all of the finance needed.</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>Types of Investment</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Expansion</p></td><td>
<p>Companies that have developed a product but now need fmancing to<br>start production and sales activities. These companies do not show a<br>profit.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Growth/Mature</p></td><td>
<p>Financing of growth and expansion of companies that has obtained<br>break even or shows a positive result. The fmancing can be used to<br>increase production capacity, marketing, and development of products<br>and to more Capital employed.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>International</p>
<p>Expansion</p></td><td>
<p>As “Expansion” but the expansion is principally abroad.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>MBO</p></td><td>
<p>An existing management team buying a company or division of a<br>company from its present owners (Management buy-out). Generally<br>well-established, profitable businesses.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>MBI</p></td><td>
<p>As with an MBO, but with a new management team brought in, often<br>to tum the company around (Management buy-in).</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Mezzanine</p></td><td>
<p>A company whose floatation on a quoted market is imminent. (Also<br>used to describe a type of finance in larger deals which combines a<br>small equity involvement with loans secured on a company’s assets)</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Quoted</p></td><td>
<p>A company quoted on the full market or similar foreign exchange.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Seed</p></td><td>
<p>Financing of research and concept development, before the start-up<br>phase.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Start-up</p></td><td>
<p>Financing of product development and launching. The company may<br>be under formation or have been established for a short period, but has<br>not sold the product commercially.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p></td><td>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund</p>
<p>Private Equity Portfolio Investment Report</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Written Down</p></td><td>
<p>An investment which has been valued significantly below its original<br>cost, but which is likely to recover at least part of its cost.</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Written Off</p></td><td>
<p>An investment from which there is no likelihood of any recovery of<br>the amount invested.</p></td></tr>
</table>
