<p>Appendices</p>
<p>A Risk Warnings</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 7<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>1 Introduction</p>
<p>l. 1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Objective of evaluation</p>
<p>The Ministry of Finance has commissioned William M. Mercer Ltd to evaluate each<br>AP Fund. The objective of the assignment is to evaluate each Fund’s organisational<br>structure in light of the mandate it has been given. Particular focus will be placed on<br>the risk Controls and the Fund’s ongoing compliance with the objectives set by its<br>Board. The evaluation of the Investment Policy will cover overall methodology,<br>objectives and assumptions used when performing the Asset Liability Study.</p>
<p>Our review has been based on a review of working papers and documents provided by<br>the Funds, telephone conversations and an onsite visit. We would like to stress that our<br>mandate was limited to carrying out a high level review of the Funds, and not a<br>detailed due diligence of the organisation and the investment policy setting.</p>
<p>1.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of the AP Fund’s mandate</p>
<p>The Seventh AP Fund has a mandate to manage 2 funds as follows:</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Premium Savings Fund: the default choice in the Premium Reserve System.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Premium Choice Fund: a fund for active choice in the Premium Reserve<br>System.</p>
<p>1.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of key responsibilities of each AP Fund Board</p>
<p>Each AP Fund has a team of permanent staff responsible for putting into effect the<br>decisions taken by the Fund’s goveming Board.</p>
<p>The number of Board members for each Fund (with the exception of the Sixth AP<br>Fund) is set to 9 members. The Board’s main responsibilities are to establish the<br>investment policy, governance policy and Risk Control Plan for the Fund in question.<br>The Board can delegate responsibilities to its support staff.</p>
<p>Stephen Woodcock</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>Johan Sidenmark</p>
<p>For and on behaif of<br>William M Mercer Limited</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 7<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2 Review of organisation</p>
<p>2.1 Overall Organisation</p>
<p>The organisation is divided into three basic areas: Asset Management, Research and<br>Fund Administration. The Fund has decided to adopt a top-down organisational<br>structure with well-defined roles and responsibilities for both teams and individuals.</p>
<p>The head of Asset Management, the head of Research and the head of Fund<br>Administration all report to the Executive President who in tum reports to the Board.</p>
<p>The Asset Management section includes two domestic Swedish desks (equities and<br>fixed income), a foreign exchange desk plus responsibility for extemal managers.</p>
<p>The Research section has responsibility for, among other things, strategic policy and<br>ALM.</p>
<p>Fund Administration handles contacts with the custodian and the trade-reporting<br>functions of the investment managers, as well as having responsibility for IT.</p>
<p>The complete organisation of 12 employees as at 2001 is illustrated in the organisation<br>chart below:</p>
<p>Board of Directors</p><img src="https://data.riksdagen.se/fil/GO03131/skr_200001__131-449.png" style="width:228pt;height:178pt;"/>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>The organisation was set up from scratch over six months in 2000. The aim was to<br>keep it small and flexible. The Fund would focus on those areas that could be<br>managed effectively in-house, with all other functions outsourced. The overall<br>structure was designed to be efficient and transparent.</p>
<p>A project plan was devised to implement the structure, as follows:</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An ALM study, with second opinions</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An IT study followed by implementation of the conclusions</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selection of extemal managers</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A publicity campaign (including a roadshow)</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Recruitment of further staff</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Establishment of a website</p>
<p>2.2 Management of Assets</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The process of establishing investment policy begins with the Board, which sets<br>investment objectives for the two funds and makes a final decision on<br>investment strategy.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the legislative objectives, the Board defined its own objectives as<br>follows:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Premium Saving Fund: The total performance shall be as least as great as<br>the performance of the average fund in the Premium Reserve system, but<br>with lower risk (rolling 5 year).</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Premium Choice Fund: The total performance shall be in the upper<br>quartile compared with other funds in the Premium Reserve System<br>(rolling 5 year).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In-house asset management is limited to Swedish assets where it is believed that<br>a small team can add value at a low cost. Swedish equity is managed actively<br>in-house but it was felt that the intemal team should be made to compete with<br>extemal managers. As a result, Swedish equity is also managed extemally on<br>both a passive and active basis, with State Street as passive manager and Carlson<br>as active.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In-house domestic bond management is passive and currency hedging is also<br>carried out in-house.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The selection of extemal managers began with a tender process for a passive<br>mandate covering the whole of the Fund’s assets, with the exception of domestic<br>Swedish bonds. Standard procedures for tenders of govemment mandates were<br>followed for the passive mandate, but on a time-constrained basis. This ensured<br>that, despite the short set-up period, the Fund was able to receive the initial<br>payments made to it in September and December 2000.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>Key to the selection of a passive investment manager was the requirement that<br>the manager be able to meet the Fund’s onerous trade-reporting standards. The<br>Fund required that trades be reported via secure web-link within 15 minutes of<br>confirmation of execution and that all trades during a day be confirmed by 4pm<br>Swedish time. The Fund also wished to minimise investment management fees,<br>so far as possible.</p>
<p>The Choice Fund posed special problems in implementation as it was decided<br>that the Fund should have the same investment management structure as the<br>Savings Fund. The amount of money initially invested with the Choice Fund<br>made establishment of a viable passive portfolio difficult. The Fund was<br>eventually able to reach a solution with its selected passive manager, State<br>Street.</p>
<p>Lengthier tender processes were followed for active mandates in Swedish,<br>European (ex Sweden), Japanese and Asia Pacific equity mandates. The Fund<br>took a policy decision to manage the entire North American equity allocation<br>passively on the grounds that this market offered insufficient opportunity to add<br>value through active management.</p>
<p>On-site visits were made to all short-listed candidates for the actively managed<br>mandates. Apart from the necessary condition that shortlisted candidates should<br>have sufficient prospects for future outperformance of their benchmarks, the<br>Fund once again focused on IT capability (and, in particular, the capacity to<br>meet the Fund’s onerous trade-reporting requirements) and on fees.</p>
<p>All extemal managers were or will be asked to sign a Fund-specific contract<br>drawn up by the Fund’s legal advisers and falling under Swedish jurisdiction.<br>Contract negotiations have been, we understand, protracted in some cases.</p>
<p>As part of the mandate, each active manager has been set a limit on experienced<br>(ex-post) tracking error plus a retum target of+1% per annum in excess of the<br>relevant benchmark. The managers have been asked to identify the sorts of<br>circumstances in which a breach of the tracking error limit might take place. If a<br>breach does occur, the Board will decide how to proceed and the Fund can, if<br>necessary, terminate its contract with each manager instantly.</p>
<p>In aggregate, the Board has laid down a tracking error limit of 3% per annum for<br>the Fund. Two thirds of the Fund will be passively managed, however, at a<br>tracking error of 0.5% per annum. This permits the Fund some room for<br>manoeuvre in structuring the mandates for its active managers.</p>
<p>Tactical asset allocation is not attempted by the Fund. Rebalancing to the<br>strategic benchmark is conducted passively on an annual basis to take advantage<br>of large annual cash inflows to the Fund, thereby avoiding unnecessary<br>transaction costs.</p>
<p>A weekly performance report is prepared by the Research team and a more<br>comprehensive monthly report. Both are reviewed by the Investment<br>Committee and the Board of Directors. The Fund has tended extemally for an<br>independent performance measurement service.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 7<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>2.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Operation</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fund uses Nordea as custodian bank. The Fund has persuaded Nordea to<br>accept responsibility for all sub-custodians.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund has selected TMS 2000 as its administration platform. It is used to<br>provide a portfolio monitoring system for the total Fund and for the daily<br>computation of net asset value for both funds. It provides the portfolio<br>interrogation facility for the intemal investment team.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Via the direct web-link to the Fund’s extemal investment managers and TMS,<br>the Fund has close to real-time data on its total portfolio.</p>
<p>2.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;People</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The level of resource put in place to manage each AP Fund is individually set by<br>each Fund itself. It is the Board of Directors and Executive Presidenfs<br>responsibility that the organisation’s resources are appropriate to its mandate.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Board appoints the Executive President and, in addition, is responsible for<br>broad investment objectives, policy and adherence to the relevant legislation. A<br>number of functions have been delegated to an Investment Committee consisting<br>of the four most senior staff.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Investment Committee has responsibility for the following:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;monitoring and measurement of the Fund</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;annual review of investment strategy</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;re-balancing according to defined limits</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;appointment and retention of extemal managers</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;control and approval of agreements with extemal managers</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;allocation of assets and limits for extemal managers</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Executive President has responsibility for:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ensuring that the ongoing management of the Fund is in compliance with<br>the Board’s investment policy</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;implementing the Board’s decisions on investment policy</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;reporting to the Board</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;decisions taken by the investment committee</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;deciding indices and benchmarks</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The head of Asset Management is also the Deputy Executive President with<br>responsibility for managing the intemal investment desks, currency hedging and<br>evaluation of each extemal portfolio manager’s performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The head of Fund Administration has responsibility for investment<br>administration, monitoring of extemal managers’ compliance with investment<br>mandate restrictions, and performance measurement calculations.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The head of Research has responsibility for ongoing evaluation of the strategic<br>asset allocation, identification of benchmarks and establishing methods for<br>evaluation of performance and risk.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In total, the Fund employs just 12 people.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s senior team believes that the existing levels of remuneration are<br>competitive. There is ongoing work to establish an incentive program that will<br>follow the guidelines for State owned companies. The Fund is tendering a<br>mandate for advice on incentive structures.</p>
<p>2.5 Mercer View</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On the whole, the Fund’s organisational approach is impressive. The central<br>aim of producing a small, flexible and efficient operation focused on a small set<br>of core skills with all other functions outsourced appears to have been achieved.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Particularly impressive is the way the Fund has been organised to streamline the<br>reporting functions between the investment managers, the counterparties and the<br>custodian bank. Everything is dealt with within TMS 2000, and in effect, the<br>fund has tumed over the administrative burden to its service providers, including<br>the investment managers.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Given the number of people employed by the Fund, the focus on domestic<br>Swedish assets is as much as could be achieved in-house and outsourcing other<br>functions makes sense. The Fund has, in addition, been careful to identify those<br>areas in which it is prepared to ask extemal firms to take on risk on its behaif. It<br>is notable that this is the only AP Fund that does not attempt to (or envisage<br>attempting to) overlay any tactical asset allocation to the strategic benchmark,<br>which is an area that concerns us to a degree in the other Funds.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The one area we would question is the lack of an incentive scheme which might<br>cause problems in the future.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of being a “trophy” client has been exploited to best effect in terms of<br>pricing, mandate guidelines (the tracking error requirement, in particular) and<br>the special trade reporting requirements.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>3 ALM</p>
<p>3.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Introduction</p>
<p>&quot; AP7’s investment strategy was determined with the assistance of an<br>asset/liability modelling exercise conducted by Watson Wyatt during 2000.</p>
<p>3.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Objectives</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As AP7 was given an objective of running two funds, the Premiesparfonden<br>(“Savings Fund”) and the Premievalsfonden (“Choice Fund”), separate<br>investment objectives were identified for each fund.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Drawing on the objectives laid down in the goveming legislation, AP7’s central<br>objectives were chosen as follows:</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Savings Fund: to match or exceed the return on the average fund in the<br>Premium Reserve system, but at a lower level of risk (rolling 5 year);</p>
<p>- &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Choice Fund: to achieve a return equal to or better than the upper quartile<br>fund in the Premium Reserve System (rolling 5 year).</p>
<p>3.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;Methodology/Assumptions</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The projection period was decided by reference to the average investor in the<br>Savings Fund. This lead to a primary projection period for asset/liability<br>modelling work of 17 years, although other periods were also considered.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Establishing the asset distribution of the average fund in the Premium Reserve<br>system was not easy in advance of initial contributions being paid. It was<br>assumed that the average fund would have 75% in equity (with roughly half of<br>that in the Swedish market) and almost all the rest in Swedish fixed income<br>bonds, with a small balancing cash allocation.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Constraints were imposed on the portfolios that were considered. The Savings<br>Fund has a 50% to 90% equity range within its published guidelines. For the<br>purposes of strategic anaiysis, the equity weighting was limited to a maximum<br>of 85% (to provide some margin for manoeuvre before the published 90% limit<br>was breached). The Choice Fund was unconstrained.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No single definition of risk was identified. Instead, an optimisation process was<br>carried out on a number of different definitions, including risk relative to<br>achievement of a real return, risk relative to inflation-linked Swedish bonds and<br>risk relative to the peer group average retum.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The asset model used was the Wilkie model.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assets were divided into the following classes: Swedish equity, global (ex<br>Sweden) equity (hedged and unhedged), Swedish medium-dated fixed income<br>bonds, global long-dated fixed income bonds (hedged and unhedged), Swedish<br>inflation-linked bonds, global (ex Sweden) inflation-linked bonds (hedged) and<br>cash.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Return assumptions were based to some degree on very long-term observed<br>historical differentials in performance between asset classes and re-based to the<br>yields currently available on bonds of different types. Asset volatilities were<br>derived largely from historical experience. A distinction was made between<br>domestic Swedish equity and international equity both in return and risk terms.</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the main study, AP7 obtained a number of second opinions on<br>their analysis.</p>
<p>3.4 Analysis of Results</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A high equity weighting was found to be appropriate regardless of the precise<br>nature of the optimisation, a fact arising primarily from the need to generate<br>returns consistent with the average fund in the Premium Reserve system, but at a<br>lower risk level.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At most moderate risk levels, partially-hedged international equities were<br>favoured over domestic equities. Swedish index-linked bonds offered the best<br>risk-reduction.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These two factors led the Fund to identify a strategy for the Savings Fund that<br>offered a slightly higher expected return than the assumed average fund, but at a<br>lower risk level.</p>
<p>The strategy chosen and since implemented is as follows:</p>
<table border="1">
<tr><td>
<p>Asset Class</p></td><td>
<p>-----—--------—</p>
<p>Benchmark Weight</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Swedish Equity</p></td><td>
<p>20%</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>International Equity (50% hedge)</p></td><td>
<p>65%</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Swedish index-linked bonds</p></td><td>
<p>14%</p></td></tr>
<tr><td>
<p>Cash</p></td><td>
<p>1%</p></td></tr>
</table>
<p>The self-imposed limit of 85% equity appears to have acted as a constraint,<br>although the Fund explains that, in fact, 85% was roughly optimal. An increase<br>in the limit would not have seen a shift in the benchmark equity weight, as this<br>would have made the Fund too risky relative to the assumed peer group average.</p>
<p>In practice, we understand that the assumed peer group average underestimated<br>the level of equity actually seen within the Premium Reserve system. The Fund<br>should therefore expect to lie comfortably within its lower risk constraint,<br>although the expected retum may no longer exceed that of the average fund.<br>The Fund expects to undertake frequent reviews of strategic policy, which will<br>take into account developments in the average fund. The first review has already</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>AP Fund 7<br>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>been undertaken and the Fund has decided to increase the strategic equity<br>weighting from 85% to 90%.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Choice Fund adopted a higher equity weighting than the Savings Fund, with<br>only marginal allocations to Swedish index-linked bonds and to cash.</p>
<p>3.5 Mercer View</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Fund’s strategic analysis has been detailed and has essentially been driven<br>by the Board’s decision to set an objective by reference to the peer group<br>average fund. This objective was itself driven in part by a legislative objective.<br>There is perhaps a question over whether the terms of reference given to the<br>Seventh AP Fund automatically lead it to adopt a strategy in the Savings Fund<br>that is in the aggregate best interests of its investors. We may take a slightly less<br>sanguine view of long-term exposure to equity risk than the Fund’s principle<br>strategic analysis appears to take. In general, achieving a retum at least as great<br>as the average fund but at lower risk is never going to be easy.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On its own, the analysis resulting from the ALM does appear to justify the<br>strategic decision taken, given the objective adopted. Certain assumptions were<br>stress-tested in reaching the conclusion and the Fund took second opinions on<br>the strategy review itself, which did lead to some changes (such as the decisions<br>to use a pure market capitalisation weighted benchmark for international<br>equities, rather than a fixed weight benchmark).</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;However our mandate does not extend to replicating the modelling process<br>ourselves and so it is not possible to draw firm conclusions on the reliability of<br>the analysis. The model used is widely (although certainly not universally)<br>accepted and the work was carried out by a reputable firm . While our analysis<br>might have yielded different results, this would most likely be driven by more<br>subjective judgements on the mechanics of markets and so would not, of itself,<br>invalidate the analysis used by the Fund.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4 Overall Assessment</p>
<p>4.1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section is intended to be an overall assessment based on our discussions with all<br>the Funds. Some of the points are more relevant to some Funds and less to others.</p>
<p>4.2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have been impressed by the overall quality, experience and motivation of the<br>professionals that we met. Hard work has accomplished a great deal in a relatively<br>short time span, either to create a totally new organisation or to undertake a major re-<br>structuring of existing funds.</p>
<p>4.3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In spite of new Board of Directors that include a varying proportion of non-initiated<br>people, they have also clearly risen to the challenge and have worked diligently with<br>management to set the framework for operating the system. To ensure their continuing<br>support, and although we understand the spirit of public service in Sweden, we wonder<br>if their remuneration could not be raised from the current SKr. 50,000 p.a.</p>
<p>4.4 &nbsp;&nbsp;We have the same kind of concerns regarding the compensation of the fund<br>professionals. While we can understand the attraction of the challenge of these new<br>funds for investment professionals, with the focus on hands on investment<br>management and an absence of bureaucracy compared with the mega-financial<br>institutions of today, at one point money does talk. Our concern is mostly on the bonus<br>side where the 6 months salary cap is clearly not in line with industry practice.<br>Personnel retention may become a real issue, especially as other third party managers<br>will come to view these people as providing an entry point into these funds. Although<br>we must emphasise that we have in no way detected this, it might be natural for<br>investment professionals to view a couple of years at an AP Fund in the same light and<br>good on a resumé. This is some thing we have observed with the investment teams of<br>Central Banks or Generational Funds. If this were to occur, it would clearly be<br>detrimental to the long term performance of the Funds.</p>
<p>4.5 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another aspect to this, is that it seem to us that the intent of the legislator in setting up<br>these competing funds was to generate a healthy competition to boost the overall risk<br>adjusted return of the buffer fund system. This would be better accomplished by a<br>clear linkage between value creation and remuneration, including short and longer<br>term incentives. The opposite risk in the absence of this linkage is that all the funds<br>will basically revert over time to a peer group average.</p>
<p>4.6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have found all the funds to place risk control at the forefront of their concerns<br>which is clearly within their mandate. By and large this is monitored in an appropriate<br>fashion in terms of its independence from investment management, reporting lines to<br>the CEO/Board and the type of reports. The only fundamental observation for possible<br>review, is that risk management cannot be condensed into one statistic, notably<br>tracking error, but must be reviewed in multiple cuts to understand the type of risk the<br>overall fund is taking and whether these are consistent with the house view or among<br>the various internal/external mandates. We suspect that for the most part this is being</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>10 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131</p>
<p>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>done, (for example some of the Funds are using BARRA type analysis) but our<br>cursory review of necessity could not reveal this in detail. We would also suggest that<br>risk management become fully integrated as part of the investment management<br>process (some of the funds do this already).</p>
<p>4.7 &nbsp;&nbsp;The Funds tend to use domestic custodians (some use domestic and non-domestic<br>custodians). Although we did not have an opportunity to review this in detail, our<br>sense is that the risk and compliance services provided by custodians (the global<br>players) may be under utilised.</p>
<p>4.8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another observation for at least careful debate is whether the overall implementation<br>of tactical asset allocation overlay programs, with the notable exception of one of the<br>Funds, is necessarily appropriate given that this is an activity that requires skills that<br>are difficult to find and in which it is difficult to, consistently, add value.</p>
<p>4.9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;What is also interesting to us is that while the Funds have easily turned to extemal<br>managers to complement their intemal expertise, this has not been the case for tactical<br>asset allocation, at least to gain an insight into some highly specialist managers are<br>doing in this area. This would seem to be the approach of some of the long standing,<br>sophisticated, in-house pension fund teams around the world, who do intemal<br>modelling but benchmark their approaches with outside TAA managers as well</p>
<p>4.10 &nbsp;A similar comment as in the previous paragraph, could cover the intent expressed in<br>most instances to make more active currency bets, especially as the currency exposure<br>regulations become more liberal over time. This is also an area of quite specific<br>expertise.</p>
<p>4.11 &nbsp;&nbsp;In fact a general observation is that the Funds might be trying to do too much,<br>especially in such a short period. It is sometimes better practice to implement a few<br>steps at a time, checking the procedures and finding the flaws in periods of difficult<br>market conditions. A related point is that a number of the Funds have devised<br>structures/process on the basis of their perceived investment management strengths.<br>This is only natural, we would however urge the Funds to consider carefully the full<br>investment opportunity set and the best way of accessing this.</p>
<p>4.12 &nbsp;Those Funds which have carried out the strategy setting exercise have done so, in<br>general, thoroughly. The areas that we feel are worthy of further analysis are strategies<br>that provide for less correlated exposure to the fortunes of the Sweden economy. A<br>number of the strategies have a bias to Swedish equities on the ground of a link<br>between wage growth and the Swedish equity market, it would be interesting to<br>explore whether there is any evidence for this.</p>
<p>4.13 &nbsp;We would concur with an observation which was often made to us, that the Public<br>Authority status of the funds, on balance was not helpful. This touches on the<br>compensation issues mentioned above, but also the everyday regulatory burden that<br>this imposes. A particular aspect of this is the somewhat uncertain mandate of AP6<br>which in limiting its private equity investments to Sweden, might imply a social<br>responsibility to assist Swedish start-ups whatever their merits. This is being resisted,<br>as illustrated by the number of deals offered to the fund and the high number that are<br>being turned down, but there is the perception of political sensitivities that at one point<br>might be detrimental to the performance of the fund.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>11 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>
<p>Evaluation Of Organisation And Investment Policy</p>
<p>Skr. 2000/01:131<br>Bilaga 6</p>
<p>4.14 It might be a good idea to introduce some economic measures of how the AP Fund<br>organisations are accomplishing their mandate. This implies the active monitoring of<br>intemal versus extemal asset management, but also the “bottom line” of the funds<br>themselves. In our experience there is no clear cut model of in-house versus total<br>outsourcing, and various combinations, as in Sweden, are generally accepted , at least<br>in the public area, like the State pension funds in the US or the generational funds<br>(ADIA, MAS, Norway Oil Fund). There has been a trend away from in-house in the<br>private sector but mostly because of focus of resources or the desire to unlock value.</p>
<p>William M. Mercer Limited<br>Investment Consulting</p>
<p>12 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AP Fund 7</p>

<p>Appendix A</p>
<p>Risk Warnings</p>
<p>* &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Past performance cannot be relied upon as a guide to future performance.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of stocks and shares, including unitised funds, can go down as well as up and<br>you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of bonds and other fixed income investments including unitised funds can go<br>down as well as up and you may not get back the amount you have invested.</p>
<p>■ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments denominated in a foreign currency will fluctuate with the value of the<br>currency.</p>
<p>• &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The value of investments in real property can go down as well as up, and you may not<br>get back the amount you have invested. Valuation is generally a matter of a valuer’s<br>opinion, rather than fact. It may be difficult or impossible to realise an investment<br>because the property concerned may not be readiiy saleable.</p>
